sa:
धृतराष्ट्र उवाच धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः ।
मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत संजय ॥
tl:
dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā
yuyutsavaḥ māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kimakurvata saṃjaya
en:
Dhritraashtr said:
Sanjay, let me know what my children and Paandu’s children are doing now that they have gathered on the sacred soil of the battlefield Kuruchhaytr, eager to fight.

sa:
. संजय उवाच दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा ।
आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् ॥
tl:
. saṃjaya uvāca dṛṣṭvā tu
pāṇḍavānīkaṃ vyūḍhaṃ duryodhanastadā ācāryamupasaṅgamya rājā vacanamabravīt
en:
Sanjay said:
Venerable sir, seeing the army of the Paandavs drawn up for battle, King Duryodhan approached Dronaachaarya and spoke these words:

sa:
: पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम् ।
व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता ॥
tl:
: paśyaitāṃ pāṇḍuputrāṇāmācārya mahatīṃ camūm
vyūḍhāṃ drupadaputreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
en: Master, behold the mighty army of the sons of Paandu arrayed for battle by your most talented pupil Dhrishtadyumn, the son of Drupad.

sa:
. अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि ।
युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः ॥
tl:
. atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjunasamā
yudhi yuyudhāno virāṭaśca drupadaśca mahārathaḥ
en: In the army of Paandu’s sons, mighty heroes, equal in military prowess to Bheem and Arjun, wield their powerful bows. I see Saatyaki and Viraat, Mahaarathi Drupad, Dhrishtakaytu, Chaykitaan, and the valiant King of Kaashi; also Purujit, Kuntibhoj, and Shaibya, the best of men. There are other mighty heroes as well: Yudhaamanyu, Uttamaujaa, Saubhadraa’s son Abhimanyu, and the five sons of Draupadi, all of them mahaarathis, warrior chiefs.

sa:
धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् ।
पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः ॥
tl: dhṛṣṭaketuścekitānaḥ kāśirājaśca vīryavān purujitkuntibhojaśca śaibyaśca narapuṅgavaḥ
en: In the army of Paandu’s sons, mighty heroes, equal in military prowess to Bheem and Arjun, wield their powerful bows. I see Saatyaki and Viraat, Mahaarathi Drupad, Dhrishtakaytu, Chaykitaan, and the valiant King of Kaashi; also Purujit, Kuntibhoj, and Shaibya, the best of men. There are other mighty heroes as well: Yudhaamanyu, Uttamaujaa, Saubhadraa’s son Abhimanyu, and the five sons of Draupadi, all of them mahaarathis, warrior chiefs.

sa:
युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् ।
सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः ॥
tl:
yudhāmanyuśca vikrānta uttamaujāśca vīryavān
saubhadro draupadeyāśca sarva eva mahārathāḥ
en: In the army of Paandu’s sons, mighty heroes, equal in military prowess to Bheem and Arjun, wield their powerful bows. I see Saatyaki and Viraat, Mahaarathi Drupad, Dhrishtakaytu, Chaykitaan, and the valiant King of Kaashi; also Purujit, Kuntibhoj, and Shaibya, the best of men. There are other mighty heroes as well: Yudhaamanyu, Uttamaujaa, Saubhadraa’s son Abhimanyu, and the five sons of Draupadi, all of them mahaarathis, warrior chiefs.

sa:
. अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम ।
नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते ॥
tl:
. asmākaṃ tu viśiṣṭā ye tānnibodha
dvijottama nāyakā mama sainyasya saṃjñārthaṃ tānbravīmi te
en: O best of Braahmans, now hear the principle generals and warriors on our side.

sa:
. भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः ।
अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च ॥
tl:
. bhavānbhīṣmaśca karṇaśca kṛpaśca
samitiñjayaḥ aśvatthāmā vikarṇaśca saumadattistathaiva ca
en: They are, including yourself, Bheeshm, Karn, Krip, Ashwatthaamaa, Vikarn, and Bhoorishravaa, all of them forever victorious in battle.

sa:
. अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः ।
नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः ॥
tl:
. anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā
madarthe tyaktajīvitāḥ nānāśastrapraharaṇāḥ sarve yuddhaviśāradāḥ
en: There are many other heroes as well, all skilled in warfare and fully armed with their various weapons and missiles. All have staked their lives for me.

sa:
. अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम् ।
पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम् ॥
tl:
. aparyāptaṃ tadasmākaṃ balaṃ
bhīṣmābhirakṣitam paryāptaṃ tvidameteṣāṃ balaṃ bhīmābhirakṣitam
en: I think that this army of ours is unconquerable, for it is fully protected by Bheeshm. On the other hand, their army, even though guarded in every way by Bheem, will be easy to conquer.

sa:
. अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः ।
भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि ॥
tl:
. ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathābhāgamavasthitāḥ
bhīṣmamevābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi
en: Now, take up your respective positions and, in particular, guard Bheeshm on every side.

sa:
: तस्य संजनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः ।
सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् ॥
tl:
: tasya saṃjanayanharṣaṃ kuruvṛddhaḥ pitāmahaḥ
siṃhanādaṃ vinadyoccaiḥ śaṅkhaṃ dadhmau pratāpavān
en:
Sanjay continued:
At that moment, Bheeshm, the grand old man of the Kaurav race, their glorious grand uncle, perceiving the concern of King Duryodhan, let out a terrifying roar like a lion and blew on his conch in order to raise the king’s spirits.

sa:
. ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः ।
सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत् ॥
tl: . tataḥ śaṅkhāśca bheryaśca paṇavānakagomukhāḥ sahasaivābhyahanyanta sa śabdastumulo’bhavat
en: Then many more conches, and kettledrums, tabours, drums, and trumpets suddenly blared forth, creating a tumultuous din.

sa:
. ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ ।
माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः ॥
tl:
. tataḥ śvetairhayairyukte mahati syandane
sthitau mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaścaiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ
en: At the same time, on the other side, Shri Krishn and Arjun, seated in a glorious chariot drawn by white horses, blew their celestial conches.

sa:
. पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनंजयः ।
पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः ॥
tl:
. pāñcajanyaṃ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṃ dhanaṃjayaḥ
pauṇḍraṃ dadhmau mahāśaṅkhaṃ bhīmakarmā vṛkodaraḥ
en: Shri Krishn blew His conch known as Paanchjanya; Arjun blew his, named Dayvadatt; and Bheem of terrible deeds blew his mighty conch, Paundr.

sa:
. अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः ।
नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ ॥
tl: . anantavijayaṃ rājā kuntīputro yudhiṣṭhiraḥ nakulaḥ sahadevaśca sughoṣamaṇipuṣpakau
en: King Yudhishthir, the eldest son of Kunti, blew his conch known as Anantvijay; Nakul blew his conch, Sughosh; and Sahadayv blew his, named Manipushpak.

sa:
. काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः ।
धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः ॥
tl:
. kāśyaśca parameṣvāsaḥ śikhaṇḍī
ca mahārathaḥ dhṛṣṭadyumno virāṭaśca sātyakiścāparājitaḥ
en: The King of Kaashi, the warrior Shikhandee, Dhrishtadyumn, Viraat, the invincible Saatyaki, Drupad, the five sons of Draupadi, and the mighty-armed Abhimanyu, son of Saubhadraa, generally and from all sides blew their conches.

sa:
द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते ।
सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक् ॥
tl: drupado draupadeyāśca sarvaśaḥ pṛthivīpate saubhadraśca mahābāhuḥ śaṅkhāndadhmuḥ pṛthakpṛthak
en: The King of Kaashi, the warrior Shikhandee, Dhrishtadyumn, Viraat, the invincible Saatyaki, Drupad, the five sons of Draupadi, and the mighty-armed Abhimanyu, son of Saubhadraa, generally and from all sides blew their conches.

sa:
. स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् ।
नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलो व्यनुनादयन् ॥
tl:
. sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṃ hṛdayāni
vyadārayat nabhaśca pṛthivīṃ caiva tumulo vyanunādayan
en: The terrible sound echoing through heaven and earth rent the hearts of Dhritraashtr’s sons and of those who sided with them.

sa:
. अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान्कपिध्वजः ।
प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसंपाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः ॥
tl: . atha vyavasthitāndṛṣṭvā dhārtarāṣṭrānkapidhvajaḥ pravṛtte śastrasaṃpāte dhanurudyamya pāṇḍavaḥ
en:
O Lord of the earth, having observed your sons arrayed against him and seeing that missiles were ready to be hurled, Arjun, son of Paandu, took up his bow and addressed the following words to Shri Krishn:
Arjun said:
Krishn, place my chariot between the two armies drawn up for battle and keep it there until I have carefully observed the warriors whom I am to fight.

sa:
हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते ।
अर्जुन उवाच सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत ॥
tl:
hṛṣīkeśaṃ tadā vākyamidamāha mahīpate arjuna
uvāca senayorubhayormadhye rathaṃ sthāpaya me’cyuta
en:
O Lord of the earth, having observed your sons arrayed against him and seeing that missiles were ready to be hurled, Arjun, son of Paandu, took up his bow and addressed the following words to Shri Krishn:
Arjun said:
Krishn, place my chariot between the two armies drawn up for battle and keep it there until I have carefully observed the warriors whom I am to fight.

sa:
यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान् ।
कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन् रणसमुद्यमे ॥
tl: yāvadetānnirīkṣe’haṃ yoddhukāmānavasthitān kairmayā saha yoddhavyamasmin raṇasamudyame
en:
O Lord of the earth, having observed your sons arrayed against him and seeing that missiles were ready to be hurled, Arjun, son of Paandu, took up his bow and addressed the following words to Shri Krishn:
Arjun said:
Krishn, place my chariot between the two armies drawn up for battle and keep it there until I have carefully observed the warriors whom I am to fight.

sa:
. योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः ।
धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः ॥
tl: . yotsyamānānavekṣe’haṃ ya ete’tra samāgatāḥ dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddheryuddhe priyacikīrṣavaḥ
en: I shall examine the evil-minded Duryodhan’s well-wishers who, eager to fight, support him in this war.

sa:
. संजय उवाच एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम् ॥
tl:
. saṃjaya uvāca evamukto hṛṣīkeśo
guḍākeśena bhārata senayorubhayormadhye sthāpayitvā rathottamam
en:
Sanjay continued:
O King, thus addressed by Arjun, Shri Krishn placed the magnificent chariot between the two armies. Positioning it to face Bheeshm, Dron, and all the kings, He said: Arjun, behold these Kauravs assembled here.

sa:
भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम् ।
उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति ॥
tl: bhīṣmadroṇapramukhataḥ sarveṣāṃ ca mahīkṣitām uvāca pārtha paśyaitānsamavetānkurūniti
en:
Sanjay continued:
O King, thus addressed by Arjun, Shri Krishn placed the magnificent chariot between the two armies. Positioning it to face Bheeshm, Dron, and all the kings, He said: Arjun, behold these Kauravs assembled here.

sa:
. तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान्पार्थः पितॄनथ पितामहान् ।
आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातॄन् पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा ॥
tl: . tatrāpaśyatsthitānpārthaḥ pitṝnatha pitāmahān ācāryānmātulānbhrātṝn putrānpautrānsakhīṃstathā
en: Now Arjun looked at both the armies stationed at their positions and found among them his teachers, uncles, granduncles, even great-granduncles, maternal uncles, brothers and cousins, sons and nephews, grandnephews, fathers-in-law, friends, and supporters.

sa:
श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि ।
तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान् ॥
tl: śvaśurānsuhṛdaścaiva senayorubhayorapi tānsamīkṣya sa kaunteyaḥ sarvānbandhūnavasthitān
en: Now Arjun looked at both the armies stationed at their positions and found among them his teachers, uncles, granduncles, even great-granduncles, maternal uncles, brothers and cousins, sons and nephews, grandnephews, fathers-in-law, friends, and supporters.

sa:
. कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत् ।
अर्जुन उवाच दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम् ॥
tl:
. kṛpayā parayāviṣṭo viṣīdannidamabravīt arjuna
uvāca dṛṣṭvemaṃ svajanaṃ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṃ samupasthitam
en:
Seeing all his relations present there, Arjun was filled with deep compassion and uttered these words in sadness:
Arjun said:
Krishn, at the sight of my kinsmen arrayed against me in battle, my limbs give way, my mouth is parched, my body quivers, and my hair stands on end.

sa:
सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति ।
वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते ॥
tl:
sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṃ ca
pariśuṣyati vepathuśca śarīre me romaharṣaśca jāyate
en:
Seeing all his relations present there, Arjun was filled with deep compassion and uttered these words in sadness:
Arjun said:
Krishn, at the sight of my kinsmen arrayed against me in battle, my limbs give way, my mouth is parched, my body quivers, and my hair stands on end.

sa:
. गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते ।
न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः ॥
tl:
. gāṇḍīvaṃ sraṃsate hastāttvakcaiva paridahyate na
ca śaknomyavasthātuṃ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ
en: My bow, Gaandeev, is slipping from my hand and my skin burns all over. My brain whirls in terrible unease and I have no strength to stand anymore.

sa:
. निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव ।
न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे ॥
tl:
. nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni
keśava na ca śreyo’nupaśyāmi hatvā svajanamāhave
en: O Kayshav, I see omens of evil; I do not see that any good can come from killing my kinsmen in battle.

sa:
. न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च ।
किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा ॥
tl:
. na kāṅkṣe vijayaṃ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṃ
sukhāni ca kiṃ no rājyena govinda kiṃ bhogairjīvitena vā
en: O Krishn, I have no desire for victory, nor for kingdom, nor for pleasure. If I kill my kinsmen, what use will there be of kingdom, luxury, or even of life?

sa:
येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च ।
त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च ॥
tl:
yeṣāmarthe kāṅkṣitaṃ no rājyaṃ bhogāḥ sukhāni
ca ta ime’vasthitā yuddhe prāṇāṃstyaktvā dhanāni ca
en: Here are my teachers, uncles, sons, nephews, granduncles, great-granduncles, maternal uncles, grandnephews, fathers-in-law, brothers-in-law, and many other relations. The very persons for whose sake we desire to possess throne, luxury, and pleasure are arrayed here on the battlefield risking their lives and wealth.

sa:
आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः ।
मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा ॥
tl:
ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrāstathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ
mātulāḥ śvaśurāḥ pautrāḥ śyālāḥ sambandhinastathā
en: Here are my teachers, uncles, sons, nephews, granduncles, great-granduncles, maternal uncles, grandnephews, fathers-in-law, brothers-in-law, and many other relations. The very persons for whose sake we desire to possess throne, luxury, and pleasure are arrayed here on the battlefield risking their lives and wealth.

sa:
. एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन ।
अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते ॥
tl:
. etānna hantumicchāmi ghnato’pi madhusūdana
api trailokyarājyasya hetoḥ kiṃ nu mahīkṛte
en: O Krishn, slayer of the demon Madhu, even if it means that I am slain, I do not want to kill them. I would not want to kill them even if the throne of the three worlds were offered to me, not to speak of lordship over the earth.

sa:
. निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन ।
पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः ॥
tl: . nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrānnaḥ kā prītiḥ syājjanārdana pāpamevāśrayedasmānhatvaitānātatāyinaḥ
en: Krishn, no doubt the sons of Dhritraashtr have criminal designs, but if we kill them, sin will be our only result. How then could we hope to be happy?

sa:
तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान् ।
स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव ॥
tl:
tasmānnārhā vayaṃ hantuṃ dhārtarāṣṭrānsvabāndhavān svajanaṃ
hi kathaṃ hatvā sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava
en: Krishn, it does not seem reasonable, therefore, to kill our own relations, the sons of Dhritraashtr. How will we gain happiness by killing them?

sa:
यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः ।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम् ॥
tl:
yadyapyete na paśyanti lobhopahatacetasaḥ
kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ mitradrohe ca pātakam
en: No doubt, Krishn, these people are blinded by greed. They do not perceive any evil in destroying their own race and so are not worried about committing the sin of treason against friends. But when we ourselves clearly see that sin will accrue from the destruction of our family, why should we not think that this crime should not be committed?

sa:
कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम् ।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन ॥
tl: kathaṃ na jñeyamasmābhiḥ pāpādasmānnivartitum kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ prapaśyadbhirjanārdana
en: No doubt, Krishn, these people are blinded by greed. They do not perceive any evil in destroying their own race and so are not worried about committing the sin of treason against friends. But when we ourselves clearly see that sin will accrue from the destruction of our family, why should we not think that this crime should not be committed?

sa:
कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः ।
धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत ॥
tl: kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ dharme naṣṭe kulaṃ kṛtsnamadharmo’bhibhavatyuta
en: This much is certain: with the destruction of the family, age-old traditions disappear, virtue is lost, and vice takes hold of the entire race.

sa:
. अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः ।
स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसंकरः ॥
tl:
. adharmābhibhavātkṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kulastriyaḥ
strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya jāyate varṇasaṃkaraḥ
en: Krishn, when vice predominates, the women of the family become corrupt; upon the corruption of the women ensues the pollution of the race; and when the race is polluted, the ideal that it upheld is destroyed.

sa:
. संकरो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च ।
पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः ॥
tl:
. saṃkaro narakāyaiva kulaghnānāṃ kulasya
ca patanti pitaro hyeṣāṃ luptapiṇḍodakakriyāḥ
en: The pollution of the race weakens man and weak men are compelled to meet a hellish fate. Deprived of the observance of family traditions such as shraad and tarpan, the offering of food and water to ancestors, even the manes of the race fall from heaven.

sa:
. दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसंकरकारकैः ।
उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः ॥
tl: . doṣairetaiḥ kulaghnānāṃ varṇasaṃkarakārakaiḥ utsādyante jātidharmāḥ kuladharmāśca śāśvatāḥ
en: Thus, when man commits the evil of killing his kinsmen and thereby pollutes the race, his age-old traditions and family customs disappear.

sa:
. उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन ।
नरकेऽनियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम ॥
tl: . utsannakuladharmāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ janārdana narake’niyataṃ vāso bhavatītyanuśuśruma
en: And, Krishn, we have heard that men who loose their family traditions are condemned to hell for an indefinite time.

sa:
. अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम् ।
यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः ॥
tl:
. aho bata mahatpāpaṃ kartuṃ
vyavasitā vayam yadrājyasukhalobhena hantuṃ svajanamudyatāḥ
en: O Krishn, it is a matter of great sorrow that, though possessed of intelligence, we have set our minds on committing this terrible sin. Because of the desire for throne and enjoyment, we are intent on killing our kinsmen.

sa:
. यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः ।
धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत् ॥
tl:
. yadi māmapratīkāramaśastraṃ śastrapāṇayaḥ
dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyustanme kṣemataraṃ bhavet
en: Rather than commit this sin, I would prefer that the fully armed sons of Dhritraashtr kill me in battle even though they see me unarmed and unresisting.

sa:
. संजय उवाच एवमुक्त्वाऽर्जुनः संख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत् ।
विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः ॥
tl:
. saṃjaya uvāca evamuktvā’rjunaḥ saṃkhye
rathopastha upāviśat visṛjya saśaraṃ cāpaṃ śokasaṃvignamānasaḥ
en:
Sanjay said:
So, having spoken thus to Shri Krishn on the battlefield, Arjun, agitated with grief, threw aside his bow and arrows and sank into the rear of his chariot. A heavy gloom cast dark shadows over his face and his eyes were deeply laden with grief.
The chapter known as Arjun Vishaad Yog ends.

sa:
संजय उवाच तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम् ।
विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः ॥
tl: saṃjaya uvāca taṃ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭamaśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇam viṣīdantamidaṃ vākyamuvāca madhusūdanaḥ
en:
Shri Krishn then spoke to Arjun, who was overwhelmed with compassion and pity, whose eyes were filled with tears, and who was uneasy and sad.
Shri Krishn said:

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम् ।
अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन ॥
tl: . śrībhagavānuvāca kutastvā kaśmalamidaṃ viṣame samupasthitam anāryajuṣṭamasvargyamakīrtikaramarjuna
en: Arjun, this state of infatuation is not appropriate to the action which you have initiated at this time. It is shunned by exalted souls because it will not bring the highest state, nor will it bring glory.

sa:
. क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते ।
क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परंतप ॥
tl:
. klaibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ
pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate kṣudraṃ hṛdayadaurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha paraṃtapa
en:
O scorcher of enemies, you are a warrior. Do not yield to fear and faintheartedness. Arise and fight!
Arjun said:

sa:
अर्जुन उवाच कथं भीष्ममहं संख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन ।
इषुभिः प्रति योत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन ॥
tl:
arjuna uvāca kathaṃ bhīṣmamahaṃ saṃkhye droṇaṃ
ca madhusūdana iṣubhiḥ prati yotsyāmi pūjārhāvarisūdana
en: But Krishn, how shall I shoot my arrows at Bheeshm and Dron on the battlefield? These men are worthy of my deepest respect.

sa:
. गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान् श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके ।
हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान्रुधिरप्रदिग्धान् ॥
tl:
. gurūnahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ
bhaikṣyamapīha loke hatvārthakāmāṃstu gurūnihaiva bhuñjīya bhogānrudhirapradigdhān
en: I would prefer to survive on alms, rather than enjoy bloodstained pleasures gained by killing my noble elders.

sa:
. न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो- यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः ।
यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषाम- स्तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः ॥
tl:
. na caitadvidmaḥ kataranno garīyo- yadvā jayema yadi vā
no jayeyuḥ yāneva hatvā na jijīviṣāma- ste’vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ
en: I am so confused that I am unable to decide what I should do at this time. Should I stand and fight or run away from the battlefield? I am not sure who is going to win; and my confusion reaches its climax when I remember that the sons of my uncle Dhritraashtr, whom I do not want to kill, are arrayed against me.

sa:
. कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसंमूढचेताः ।
यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् ॥
tl:
. kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasaṃmūḍhacetāḥ yacchreyaḥ syānniścitaṃ
brūhi tanme śiṣyaste’haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam
en: Krishn, I am puzzled about my duty. My mind and heart are not co-operating with me. Therefore, I ask You to tell me that which will help me to perform my duty decisively and well.

sa:
. न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद् यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम् ।
अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् ॥
tl:
. na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād
yacchokamucchoṣaṇamindriyāṇām avāpya bhūmāvasapatnamṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇāmapi cādhipatyam
en:
Even if I were to obtain undisputed power, an affluent kingdom on earth, and lordship over the gods, I still do not see any means of removing this grief which is paralyzing my senses.
Sanjay said:

sa:
. संजय उवाच एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परंतप ।
न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह ॥
tl:
. saṃjaya uvāca evamuktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ paraṃtapa
na yotsya iti govindamuktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha
en: O King, having thus expressed himself to Shri Krishn, Arjun declared, “I will not fight!” and became silent.

sa:
. तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः ॥
tl: . tamuvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasanniva bhārata senayorubhayormadhye viṣīdantamidaṃ vacaḥ
en:
Observing the inconsistency between Arjun’s situation and this statement, Krishn, as if smiling, spoke the following words to the sorrowing Arjun in the midst of the two armies.
Shri Krishn said:

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे ।
गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः ॥
tl: . śrībhagavānuvāca aśocyānanvaśocastvaṃ prajñāvādāṃśca bhāṣase gatāsūnagatāsūṃśca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ
en: Arjun, you speak like a learned man, yet still you are feeling sorry. Wise men never grieve, either for the living or the dead.

sa:
. न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः ।
न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम् ॥
tl:
. na tvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme
janādhipāḥ na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayamataḥ param
en: I, you, and all these kings have always been in Pure Existence and will remain so forever. Therefore, you should not feel sorry for the impending death of any form.

sa:
. देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा ।
तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति ॥
tl:
. dehino’sminyathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ
jarā tathā dehāntaraprāptirdhīrastatra na muhyati
en: The truth is that the eternal Self manifests as childhood, childhood changes into youth, youth into old age, and old age into death. Even after death, the Self again assumes the form of a child and so continues on and on. These changes occur on the level of form, but the Self is forever unchanging. The wise man knows this fact and never becomes deluded.

sa:
. मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः ।
आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत ॥
tl: . mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ āgamāpāyino’nityāstāṃstitikṣasva bhārata
en: O son of Kunti, if one is in the sense of duality and experiences the objects through the senses, he feels either pleasure or pain, heat or cold, which are temporary. Ignore such feelings and do not suffer.

sa:
. यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ ।
समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते ॥
tl:
. yaṃ hi na vyathayantyete
puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ so’mṛtatvāya kalpate
en: Arjun, because the wise man is not under the influence of the sense of duality, he is unaffected by pain and pleasure. He is qualified to attain God Realization.

sa:
. नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः ।
उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः ॥
tl:
. nāsato vidyate bhāvo
nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ ubhayorapi dṛṣṭo’ntastvanayostattvadarśibhiḥ
en: They become the seers of Truth who perceive that unreality never exists and Reality never ceases to be, although its actual forms keep manifesting, changing, and dissolving.

sa:
. अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् ।
विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति ॥
tl:
. avināśi tu tadviddhi yena
sarvamidaṃ tatam vināśamavyayasyāsya na kaścitkartumarhati
en: Arjun, the Self, which pervades all beings in the universe, is an indestructible substance. No one has the power to destroy it.

sa:
. अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः ।
अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत ॥
tl:
. antavanta ime dehā
nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ anāśino’prameyasya tasmādyudhyasva bhārata
en: All the forms belonging to the formless Pure Being, which is imperishable, indefinable, and eternal, are said to be perishable and changing. Therefore, Arjun, without worrying about the destruction of these bodies before you, just perform your duty as a competent warrior on this battlefield, which is your karm bhoomi at this moment.

sa:
. य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम् ।
उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते ॥
tl:
. ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaścainaṃ manyate hatam
ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate
en: Neither he who thinks that the Self causes killing, nor he who thinks that the Self is killed by someone has realized the Truth, for the Self neither kills nor is killed.

sa:
. न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन् नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः ।
अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे ॥
tl:
. na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā
na bhūyaḥ ajo nityaḥ śāśvato’yaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
en: The Self, God, never takes birth and never dies. Even when God, having manifested, appears to have become something, taken birth, or changed into a form separate from Himself, the truth is that He is unborn, ancient, and everlasting. When a body appears to be killed or destroyed, it is only the form changing or dying; the Self remains forever the same.

sa:
. वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम् ।
कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम् ॥
tl:
. vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enamajamavyayam kathaṃ
sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam
en: Arjun, knowing that this Self is imperishable, eternal, and does not undergo the changes of birth and death, how will one cause killing and who will be killed? The cause of understanding that there is killing and being killed lies in ignorance. It is not reasonable, therefore, to grieve for the death of anyone.

sa:
. वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि ।
तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा- न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही ॥
tl:
. vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro’parāṇi
tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇā- nyanyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī
en: The Self, embodied by a form, appears to cast off that form when it is worn out and to enter into a new one, just as a man sheds worn-out clothing and puts on new. This is the truth of the Self.

sa:
. नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः ।
न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः ॥
tl:
. nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati
pāvakaḥ na cainaṃ kledayantyāpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
en: The Self is immortal. It cannot be cut by weapons, burnt by fire, wet by water, or dried by wind. It is indestructible. You must realize this.

sa:
. अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च ।
नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः ॥
tl: . acchedyo’yamadāhyo’yamakledyo’śoṣya eva ca nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇuracalo’yaṃ sanātanaḥ
en: The Self is proof against weapons, fire, water, and air. I remind you, Arjun, of its nature and qualities: it is eternal, omnipresent, unmoving, and constant.

sa:
. अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते ।
तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि ॥
tl: . avyakto’yamacintyo’yamavikāryo’yamucyate tasmādevaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitumarhasi
en: You should not grieve, thinking that the Self in manifest form is going to be destroyed. The Self is unmanifest, unfathomable, immutable.

sa:
. अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम् ।
तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥
tl:
. atha cainaṃ nityajātaṃ nityaṃ vā
manyase mṛtam tathāpi tvaṃ mahābāho naivaṃ śocitumarhasi
en: If you know that the Self is immortal, you should not grieve; and if you know that bodies are subject to inevitable and constant birth and death, again you should not grieve.

sa:
. जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च ।
तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥
tl:
. jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyurdhruvaṃ janma
mṛtasya ca tasmādaparihārye’rthe na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi
en: One who is born must die and one who dies must undergo rebirth. These changes are inevitable; you should not grieve over them.

sa:
. अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत ।
अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना ॥
tl:
. avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni
bhārata avyaktanidhanānyeva tatra kā paridevanā
en: Before birth, Arjun, beings are unmanifest, and after death they are again unmanifest. Manifestation occurs only between birth and death. This being so, what occasion is there for lamentation?

sa:
आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेन- माश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः ।
आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित् ॥
tl:
āścaryavatpaśyati kaścidena- māścaryavadvadati tathaiva cānyaḥ āścaryavaccainamanyaḥ
śṛṇoti śrutvāpyenaṃ veda na caiva kaścit
en: Hardly anyone perceives the Self as marvellous, hardly anyone speaks of it as so; rare is he who hears of it as marvellous, and many are they who, on hearing, never know what the Self is, for the nature of the Self is beyond knowing and beyond description. For this reason, even having realized the Self, only a great genius can communicate its true nature of Sat-Chit-Aanand, Pure Existence, Pure Consciousness, Pure Bliss.

sa:
. देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत ।
तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥
tl:
. dehī nityamavadhyo’yaṃ dehe sarvasya
bhārata tasmātsarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi
en: Arjun, the Self, which dwells in every body, can never be slain; therefore, you should not grieve over anyone’s destruction.

sa:
. स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि ।
धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते ॥
tl:
. svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na
vikampitumarhasi dharmyāddhi yuddhācchreyo’nyatkṣatriyasya na vidyate
en: Arjun, given your duty as the commander-in-chief of this army, you must show no sign of wavering. Nothing more welcome can happen for an honourable warrior like you than a righteous war by which he can protect the virtuous and destroy the wicked.

sa:
. यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् ।
सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम् ॥
tl:
. yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam
sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddhamīdṛśam
en: Arjun, warriors and protectors become happy when they find an opportunity to perform their duty and so open the door to the highest Space.

sa:
. अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि ।
ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि ॥
tl:
. atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na
kariṣyasi tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpamavāpsyasi
en: Again, I say to you, if you do not perform your duty in this righteous war, you will ruin your reputation. Throughout your life you will repent of having incurred a sin, because without you in this war the virtuous will not be victorious over the wicked and will perish.

sa:
. अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम् ।
संभावितस्य चाकीर्ति- र्मरणादतिरिच्यते ॥
tl:
. akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni
kathayiṣyanti te’vyayām saṃbhāvitasya cākīrti- rmaraṇādatiricyate
en: People will condemn your evasion and speak ill of you. For a man who has enjoyed great renown, the loss of his glory is worse than death.

sa:
. भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः ।
येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम् ॥
tl:
. bhayādraṇāduparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ yeṣāṃ
ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
en: The chief warriors, who hold you in high esteem, will treat you as a coward. They will hate you, thinking that due to fear you ran from battle.

sa:
. अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः ।
निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम् ॥
tl:
. avācyavādāṃśca bahūnvadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ nindantastava
sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim
en: When your enemies mock your action and belittle your power, will that not distress you more than anything else?

sa:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् ।
तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः ॥
tl:
hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā
bhokṣyase mahīm tasmāduttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ
en: If you die in this war you will surely win heaven; if you conquer you will enjoy great power on earth. Either way you will gain. Therefore, arise, Arjun, and determine to fight.

sa:
. सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ ।
ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि ॥
tl:
. sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau
jayājayau tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpamavāpsyasi
en: Establish yourself in the state of consciousness which cannot be touched by victory and defeat, gain and loss, pleasure and pain; then, ready yourself to fight. I assure you that you will incur no sin in performing your duty.

sa:
. एषा तेऽभिहिता सांख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु ।
बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि ॥
tl:
. eṣā te’bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ
śṛṇu buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi
en: Arjun, seeing that you are not reacting, I gather that your intellect has not yet become decisive and that you are wondering about the Knowledge I have presented to you. Now, listen to another point of view, which will be more helpful at this stage of your understanding, for I am aware that you need My guidance to make your intellect pure and decisive. If you understand this other point of view, you will never be bound by thoughts of whether to perform or not to perform action.

sa:
. नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते ।
स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् ॥
tl:
. nehābhikramanāśo’sti pratyavāyo na vidyate
svalpamapyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
en:
The method I am advising will not waste any of your effort. Using it, you can be free from the fear of any contrary result. Even a little practice of this method will save you from the greatest fear of all, the fear of death.
The point I am presenting is very simple. You must continually practise performing action without placing your attention on its results. The mind always acts thinking that the result of action will fulfill some expectation or desire. The practice that I am recommending will train your mind into Nishkaam Karm Yog. This means that your attention, rather than resting on the level of action, will dwell in the inner field of Pure Existence which is held in your head and heart in the state of nishkaam, or desirelessness, thoughtlessness.
When your individual attention is kept on nishkaam karm, desireless action, it will be united with or transformed into the Pure Existence of the unmoved, unwavering state of all action. This state is the emanating source of all the waves and thoughts which, when the mind is built, pertain to action. Arjun, in due course of time and practice, your present level of mental consciousness will be totally transformed into the state of nishkaam karm, in which there is no loss of energy in the performance of action. Then you will have no reason to wonder whether or not your efforts will be wasted.
In the Nishkaam Karm Yog state of existence at the source of the mind, there is no hurdle or interruption resulting from mental considerations. Once started, your action will not be interrupted by thoughts of whether or not you will succeed. Arjun, if you practise this type of action even for a short while, you will gain the power of your own true nature, Sat-Chit-Aanand, which will completely remove the fear of death, the source of all the mind’s fears.
Nishkaam Karm Yog is the practice of meditation on your true Self, which is Me. You must practise it without bothering about the result, for when you meditate on your true nature, Me, the Self, you will realize that every thought of gain and loss is only happening on the active level of the mind. This level is simply the manifest aspect of Me, the Self, whose name is Nishkaam Karm Yog. When you have realized that there is only Me, the Self, your true nature, at the base of all thinking in terms of gain and loss, happiness and unhappiness, victory and defeat, then you will have attained the Vision of God. In this Vision all the aspects of manifestation—thought, speech, action, or any happening inside or outside of you—are known to be manifestations of your own Self. In this Vision alone will you be free from all the fears which occur on the level of sakaam karm yog, the sense of duality or thought of ahankaar, in which it is held that you are separate, the world is separate, and the original giver of all action, God, is also separate somewhere.
Since, as an army general, you are concerned with performing action on the battlefield, you must be sure about the source-power of your thought, speech, and action. It is Me alone, the very Self of your own self, the Self of all manifest beings on earth. In tune with the state of Nishkaam Karm Yog, you will come to grasp on the mind level that this personality of Arjun is not the doer, that the real doer is Me, God, the Self. The individual “me” is merely a tool, a vehicle which the real Being uses for the sake of establishing the Vision of Oneness, the Knowledge that God is everywhere. Arjun, this Vision will remove the vision of duality which has taken over your enemies now arrayed against you.
By attaining the Knowledge of Nishkaam Karm Yog, in which you are merely an actor on the stage, you will be able to perform your duty perfectly free from care or fear. Arjun, adopting this attitude, which is My Knowledge, will definitely release your mind now bound in the field of ideas in which you wonder whether or not you should fight. Later on, I will reveal the specific technique of how this practice should be conducted in terms of meditation, its place, and its environment.

sa:
. व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन ।
बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ॥
tl: . vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana bahuśākhā hyanantāśca buddhayo’vyavasāyinām
en: Arjun, if you attain the transformation into Nishkaam Karm Yog of which I have just informed you, your mind will be determined, one-pointed, and decisive. The indecisive state of mind in which you are presently established will always give you trouble, so you must practise this technique of nishkaam karm while thinking, concentrating, contemplating, and meditating on Me, the Self, whose state of existence in terms of action is nishkaam.

sa:
. यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः ।
वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः ॥
tl:
. yāmimāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ
pravadantyavipaścitaḥ vedavādaratāḥ pārtha nānyadastīti vādinaḥ
en: Arjun, you should not follow the knowledge taught by those who, full of duality and devoted to the words of the Vedas, preach that the purpose of man’s life is to gain heaven. These unwise ones utter flowery speeches recommending all kinds of rituals for the attainment of pleasure and power in this world. Since their minds are carried away by the ideas of pleasure and power, they cannot attain the pure intellect which can be tuned-in to the Self. If you are to establish your intellect in your true Self, you must follow what I say.

sa:
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम् ।
क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति ॥
tl: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati
en: Arjun, you should not follow the knowledge taught by those who, full of duality and devoted to the words of the Vedas, preach that the purpose of man’s life is to gain heaven. These unwise ones utter flowery speeches recommending all kinds of rituals for the attainment of pleasure and power in this world. Since their minds are carried away by the ideas of pleasure and power, they cannot attain the pure intellect which can be tuned-in to the Self. If you are to establish your intellect in your true Self, you must follow what I say.

sa:
भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम् ।
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते ॥
tl: bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
en: Arjun, you should not follow the knowledge taught by those who, full of duality and devoted to the words of the Vedas, preach that the purpose of man’s life is to gain heaven. These unwise ones utter flowery speeches recommending all kinds of rituals for the attainment of pleasure and power in this world. Since their minds are carried away by the ideas of pleasure and power, they cannot attain the pure intellect which can be tuned-in to the Self. If you are to establish your intellect in your true Self, you must follow what I say.

sa:
. त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन ।
निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान् ॥
tl:
. traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo
bhavārjuna nirdvandvo nityasattvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān
en: The subject matter of the scriptures, or Vedas, creates in the mind dualistic impressions which contain the ideas either of loss and gain or pleasure and pain. These impressions are the result of actions performed in the light of doership, which is always mental and is always based on the ego-mechanism. The ego, or “I,” is the product of the three gunas. Since the three gunas never allow any man’s mind to be free from the ignorance of his own true Self, one must transcend this field of the gunas and become established in pure, eternal Existence, the state of freedom in which duality can never exist. Once established in Pure Consciousness, you are Pure Consciousness. The nature of that “You” will not then be doubtful or forgetful, qualities belonging to the ordinary “you” which is man’s individual consciousness. You will be your real Self, forever free from all struggles and all ideas of acquiring and preserving possessions. You will be the Pure Self which alone perceives the source of thought, action, and the result of action as one. That source alone is completely free from the interruptions which are the ideas and considerations recorded in the Vedas; for the Vedas are based on mental consciousness, which is a product of the three gunas. Transcending the considerations of your own mind, or of any mind, you will attain freedom from the influence of the three gunas. You will be Aatmawaan, that perfectly independent Consciousness, the name of which is Self.

sa:
. यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके ।
तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः ॥
tl:
. yāvānartha udapāne sarvataḥ
saṃplutodake tāvānsarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ
en: Arjun, your reaction to your situation is not in harmony with the wisdom you have expressed. The wise attach no importance to a pond when everywhere there is a flood. Likewise, you should not talk about the importance of words recorded in the Vedas, which you have learned on the mind level like a parrot, when there is the possibility of gaining the Knowledge of the Self through the technique of Nishkaam Karm Yog, which works for you while you act.

sa:
. कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन ।
मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि ॥
tl:
. karmaṇyevādhikāraste mā phaleṣu
kadācana mā karmaphalaheturbhūrmā te saṅgo’stvakarmaṇi
en: Act according to the occasion and circumstance, for you have the right to initiate any action. Do not waste your time thinking about what may happen in the future regarding the fruits of your action. By dwelling constantly on results which are as yet non-existent, you are bound to succumb to inaction and dullness. This will lead you into depression and thus you will miss the opportunity at hand. Do not, therefore, entertain any state of attachment, for you should know that attachment will lead you to inaction, and inaction brings about an early death.

sa:
. योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनंजय ।
सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते ॥
tl:
. yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā
dhanaṃjaya siddhyasiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṃ yoga ucyate
en: Arjun, know that you can develop the power of Yog which will enable you to maintain your mind in a state of perfect balance and to be unwavering and decisive in the performance of your duties. It is only in this decisive state of mind that you can perform your duty as required. The power of which I speak is not a mental awareness but is, rather, the highest Awareness, Yog Power, Yog Siddhi. It is the state of perfection called Self Realization, established in which one sees the evenness of his own true nature manifest everywhere, so that all contact and attachment with the sense of duality is finished. This state is known by the word “Yog.”

sa:
दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनंजय ।
बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः ॥
tl: dūreṇa hyavaraṃ karma buddhiyogāddhanaṃjaya buddhau śaraṇamanviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phalahetavaḥ
en: If your mind has not reached this state of the perfect power of Yog, your action and its results will be inferior and will fail to bring you the state of perfect Consciousness in the form of Yog, or equanimity. Therefore, take refuge in the balanced state of mind which does not bind you to the fruits of action. Those who do not attain non-doership are instrumental in making their actions bear fruit, karm phal, and so remain poor and wretched.

sa:
. बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते ।
तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् ॥
tl:
. buddhiyukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte
tasmādyogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
en: Arjun, listen to Me once again very carefully. The power of Yog alone frees a man’s mind from the influence of his actions and their results, such as gain and loss, good and evil. If a man cultivates this power within the deepest centre of his mind and heart, he will acquire the ability to act with such technique that he expends little energy yet produces the greatest result. Strive, therefore, to practise Nishkaam Karm Yog because, by doing so, one gains that skill in action whereby he can act yet not be bound or influenced by the results. Please establish yourself in this state of mind called samattwa buddhi, or Yog.

sa:
. कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः ।
जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम् ॥
tl:
. karmajaṃ buddhiyuktā hi phalaṃ
tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ janmabandhavinirmuktāḥ padaṃ gacchantyanāmayam
en: The truth is that one who is in tune with the wisdom and power of Yog cannot be bound by the fruits of action. Free from the idea of birth and death, he acts and attains the blissful, supreme state of mind.

sa:
. यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति ।
तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च ॥
tl:
. yadā te mohakalilaṃ buddhirvyatitariṣyati
tadā gantāsi nirvedaṃ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
en: When your mind is connected to the direct perception of Reality, you do not lay much importance on conceptual truths formed according to the influence of words spoken by others or written in scriptures. Then, you know the difference between the Truth revealed directly to you and the truths of which people are generally aware.

sa:
. श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला ।
समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि ॥
tl:
. śrutivipratipannā te yadā
sthāsyati niścalā samādhāvacalā buddhistadā yogamavāpsyasi
en:
Arjun, when your intellect, which has become confused by listening to contradictory teachings, is at rest, it will be united with your highest Self, God. It will be steady and unwavering. Then you will attain the state of Yog, which is Self Realization.
After listening to Shri Krishn’s words, Arjun asked:

sa:
. अर्जुन उवाच स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव ।
स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम् ॥
tl:
. arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya
keśava sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim
en:
Krishn, what is the mark of the God-realized being who is stable of mind and established in the Oneness of Samaadhi? How does he speak, sit, walk, and interact while living in the world?
Shri Krishn replied:

sa:
श्रीभगवानुवाच प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान् ।
आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते ॥
tl: śrībhagavānuvāca prajahāti yadā kāmānsarvānpārtha manogatān ātmanyevātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthitaprajñastadocyate
en: Arjun, the mark of a God-realized being is that he is not a slave to the craving for sense objects; rather, he rests satisfied in his own Self-awareness and, with full control and wisdom, uses his senses for the maintenance of his body. He never wavers and in the light of his awareness takes everything as it is.

sa:
. दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः ।
वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते ॥
tl: . duḥkheṣvanudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ vītarāgabhayakrodhaḥ sthitadhīrmunirucyate
en: A sage with such an established mind feels no disturbance, no craving, no sorrow, no passion, no fear, no jealousy, and no anger. His thirst for pleasure disappears altogether.

sa:
. यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् ।
नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
tl:
. yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehastattatprāpya śubhāśubham nābhinandati
na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
en: The mind of such a man is even. Whether meeting good or evil, he is ever the same; he neither rejoices over gain nor recoils from loss.

sa:
. यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
tl:
. yadā saṃharate cāyaṃ
kūrmo’ṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyastasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
en: Just as the tortoise is free to use its limbs and senses for the sake of its existence and is also free to withdraw them if need be, so the stable mind can withdraw its senses from the sense objects.

sa:
. विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः ।
रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते ॥
tl:
. viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ
rasavarjaṃ raso’pyasya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate
en: Hearing what I have said about one who is even-minded, a person of wavering mind, trying to copy the even-minded one, may plan to withdraw his senses from the sense objects in order to appear even-minded to others. Since his mind is unstable, however, relishing and hankering will persist in his thinking even though he may not actively engage in enjoying sense objects. You should not regard such a person as an ideal. Only the truly stable mind will remain balanced and even whether the senses are used or not. So, Arjun, the fulfilled state belongs to the stable mind that sees the Supreme, not to the mind that is unsteady and identified with its own little self.

sa:
. यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः ।
इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः ॥
tl:
. yatato hyapi kaunteya puruṣasya
vipaścitaḥ indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṃ manaḥ
en: Arjun, the mind of an unstable man is turbulent even if outwardly he appears to be self-controlled, learned, stable, and wise. His senses carry his wavering mind away from the centre again and again.

sa:
. तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः ।
वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
tl:
. tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yukta āsīta
matparaḥ vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
en: He who has mastered the senses is known to be of stable mind. Even while allowing his mind to associate with the objects of the senses, he keeps meditating on Me, devoting his heart and soul completely to Me.

sa:
. ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते ।
सङ्गात्संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते ॥
tl: . dhyāyato viṣayānpuṃsaḥ saṅgasteṣūpajāyate saṅgātsaṃjāyate kāmaḥ kāmātkrodho’bhijāyate
en: Now, Arjun, listen while I describe how the soul becomes bound. When a man uses his mind to dwell upon sense objects, he becomes attached to them. After developing attachment, he becomes bound by the desire to possess them at any cost, in any way. When he fails to possess them, he becomes agitated and angry.

sa:
. क्रोधाद्भवति संमोहः संमोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः ।
स्मृतिभ्रंशाद्बुद्धिनाशोबुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति ॥
tl: . krodhādbhavati saṃmohaḥ saṃmohātsmṛtivibhramaḥ smṛtibhraṃśādbuddhināśobuddhināśātpraṇaśyati
en: When anger takes possession of a man, infatuation arises, which creates confusion of memory in the intellect. From confused memory ensues the loss of reason; and when reason is lost, one is said to be in such complete ruin that his existence can no longer be effective in achieving anything worthwhile. Such a man wastes his life and passes unrecognized.

sa:
. रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् ।
आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति ॥
tl: . rāgadveṣaviyuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran ātmavaśyairvidheyātmā prasādamadhigacchati
en: The man of stable mind retains the power to enjoy the objects of the senses, but he keeps his senses disciplined, controlling his likes and dislikes in such a way that they do not disturb him at all.

sa:
. प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते ।
प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते ॥
tl: . prasāde sarvaduḥkhānāṃ hānirasyopajāyate prasannacetaso hyāśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate
en: He who has attained placidity of mind becomes aware of Oneness. His intellect withdraws from ignorance, his sorrow comes to an end, and he remains firmly established in God.

sa:
. नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना ।
न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम् ॥
tl:
. nāsti buddhirayuktasya na cāyuktasya
bhāvanā na cābhāvayataḥ śāntiraśāntasya kutaḥ sukham
en: One whose mind is unstable is undisciplined; he can neither reason about nor have faith in the higher Self, God. Without faith and reason, a man can never be at peace; and one who is not at peace can never attain happiness.

sa:
. इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनु विधीयते ।
तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि ॥
tl:
. indriyāṇāṃ hi caratāṃ yanmano’nu
vidhīyate tadasya harati prajñāṃ vāyurnāvamivāmbhasi
en: Arjun, as the wind carries away a boat upon the waters, the ignorance which moves the senses among their objects carries away the mind’s discrimination. Such a mind drowns in the ocean of the world. Therefore, do not allow your mind to become attached to the senses, for to do so will destroy your Knowledge of Oneness.

sa:
. तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
tl: . tasmādyasya mahābāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyastasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
en: O mighty-armed Arjun, he whose senses are completely restrained from contact with their objects is said to be established in the state of Self Realization.

sa:
. या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी ।
यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः ॥
tl:
. yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī
yasyāṃ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ
en: The state of Divine Knowledge and Supreme Bliss is a kind of daylight in which the God-realized yogi remains awake but in which the unrealized being sleeps. The transient pleasures derived through the sense objects are night for the God-realized being, but for the unrealized being, they are the day in which he remains awake.

sa:
. आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत् ।
तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी ॥
tl:
. āpūryamāṇamacalapratiṣṭhaṃ samudramāpaḥ praviśanti yadvat tadvatkāmā
yaṃ praviśanti sarve sa śāntimāpnoti na kāmakāmī
en: As the ocean in the rainy season is flooded by the waters of different rivers yet remains undisturbed, so they who meet undisturbed all the joys of the world remain forever at peace. On the other hand, they who hanker after enjoyment are without peace.

sa:
. विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः ।
निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति ॥
tl:
. vihāya kāmānyaḥ sarvānpumāṃścarati
niḥspṛhaḥ nirmamo nirahaṃkāraḥ sa śāntimadhigacchati
en: One who has attained peace is said to have given up all desire. He moves, completely free from the sense of ego, and so is free from yearning. He who has not attained peace remains on the level of that human consciousness called mind, whose nature and function is such that it cannot give up the desire to attain one thing or get away from another. Such a man is said to be helpless because of this inability to give up desire. Therefore, Arjun, establish yourself in the state of perfect peace and be one with God.

sa:
. एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति ।
स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति ॥
tl:
. eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha
naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati sthitvāsyāmantakāle’pi brahmanirvāṇamṛcchati
en:
Arjun, when a man realizes the true nature of his own Self, God, he is free from delusion and forever at peace. Established in this state of God Realization, which is that last moment when ignorance ends completely, he attains Brahmik Bliss in this very life.
The chapter known as Saankhya Yog ends.

sa:
अर्जुन उवाच ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन ।
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव ॥
tl:
arjuna uvāca jyāyasī cetkarmaṇaste matā buddhirjanārdana
tatkiṃ karmaṇi ghore māṃ niyojayasi keśava
en:
Arjun asked:
Why do You urge me to do this terrible deed if You consider Knowledge and Wisdom to be supreme and therefore superior to action?

sa:
व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे ।
तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् ॥
tl:
vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṃ mohayasīva me
tadekaṃ vada niścitya yena śreyo’hamāpnuyām
en: Krishn, Your words puzzle me. Please tell me in definite terms the one discipline which will remove this confusion from my mind and by which I may obtain perfect clarity regarding the performance of action.

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ ।
ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् ॥
tl:
. śrībhagavānuvāca loke’smindvividhā niṣṭhā purā
proktā mayānagha jñānayogena sāṃkhyānāṃ karmayogena yoginām
en:
Shri Krishn said:
Ajun, in this world in the past I enunciated two courses of spiritual discipline. He whose mind wants to learn about the nature of God is to be guided along the Path of Knowledge, whereas he whose mind wants to know the nature of the world through the performance of action is to be guided along the Path of Action.

sa:
. न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते ।
न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति ॥
tl:
. na karmaṇāmanārambhānnaiṣkarmyaṃ puruṣo’śnute
na ca saṃnyasanādeva siddhiṃ samadhigacchati
en: Every man wants to attain the state of perfection which is the removal of all indecisiveness, whether of knowledge or action. If, not taking up action, one just keeps sitting, waiting for perfection to dawn, he will fail to retain the freedom which will liberate him from doubt.

sa:
. न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् ।
कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः ॥
tl:
. na hi kaścitkṣaṇamapi jātu
tiṣṭhatyakarmakṛt kāryate hyavaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛtijairguṇaiḥ
en: Every human being is helplessly driven by the force of nature to perform some kind of action, for without acting man cannot live even for a moment.

sa:
. कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् ।
इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते ॥
tl:
. karmendriyāṇi saṃyamya ya āste
manasā smaran indriyārthānvimūḍhātmā mithyācāraḥ sa ucyate
en: Arjun, a man may sit still and appear as though he is not acting, but if in his mind he dwells continually upon the objects of the senses, this act of thinking is itself action. Even the very act of sitting is action. If, not knowing this, one feels gratified, thinking that by not performing action outwardly he has dropped action altogether, he is a hypocrite.

sa:
. यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन ।
कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते ॥
tl: . yastvindriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate’rjuna karmendriyaiḥ karmayogamasaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate
en: On the other hand, Arjun, he excels who controls the organs of sense and action by the power of his will and directs them towards performing the Yog of Action, which results in the state of Self Realization.

sa:
. नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः ।
शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः ॥
tl:
. niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ karma
jyāyo hyakarmaṇaḥ śarīrayātrāpi ca te na prasiddhyedakarmaṇaḥ
en: Therefore, Arjun, you should perform whatever duty you have already undertaken because action is superior to inaction. Moreover, if you desist from action and sit idle, you will not even be able to maintain your body’s existence. Then no task at all will be accomplished.

sa:
. यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः ।
तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर ॥
tl:
. yajñārthātkarmaṇo’nyatra loko’yaṃ karmabandhanaḥ
tadarthaṃ karma kaunteya muktasaṅgaḥ samācara
en: Man becomes bound when he performs action with the idea that he is the doer. When he acts for the sake of God, dedicating doership to the Almighty, he is not bound or influenced by results. Therefore, Arjun, staying free from the sense of doership, perform your duty efficiently. While acting, be aware that it is the supreme power of God that makes you think and act. Then your action will be the true act of great sacrifice.

sa:
. सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः ।
अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् ॥
tl:
. sahayajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā
purovāca prajāpatiḥ anena prasaviṣyadhvameṣa vo’stviṣṭakāmadhuk
en: When the Creator, Brahmaa, created mankind, he created as well the sense of sacrifice. In man, the nature of that sense is the ability to think of dedicating his personal ego to his own highest Consciousness, from where he derives the chaytan, or consciousness, to identify himself as a man separate from the original Reality. Having created man, Brahmaa asked him to perform all action in that spirit of sacrifice by surrendering his doings to God. Surrender is becoming one with God. That is non-doing. If man follows this advice, he will prosper while seeking enjoyment through action.

sa:
. देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः ।
परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ ॥
tl:
. devānbhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu
vaḥ parasparaṃ bhāvayantaḥ śreyaḥ paramavāpsyatha
en: Brahmaa also told man that if he performs action in the spirit of sacrifice, dedicating his doership to God, the praanik powers guiding his senses will also be nourished and will become godly. Then the gods, the subtlest forces, will be gracious. In this way, both man and his guiding forces will be fostered in joy, and in the long run all will attain the highest good in the form of Self Realization.

sa:
. इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः ।
तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः ॥
tl:
. iṣṭānbhogānhi vo devā dāsyante yajñabhāvitāḥ
tairdattānapradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
en: If the higher powers, or gods, dwelling in man are fostered by the spirit of sacrifice, man will receive all joy even without asking because the higher powers will shower their grace on him. On the other hand, a man enjoying the gifts created by the gods but offering them nothing in return is ungrateful, for the subtle powers aakaash, air, fire, water, and earth, plus the Creative Intelligence, are all the creators of the objects man enjoys. While enjoying objects, man should remain grateful to the gods; then he will stay connected to his own higher powers. Being grateful means man should know that it is God alone who is doing everything, everywhere—and God is one with such a man. In this way the sense of duality will never arise.

sa:
. यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः ।
भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् ॥
tl:
. yajñaśiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarvakilbiṣaiḥ
bhuñjate te tvaghaṃ pāpā ye pacantyātmakāraṇāt
en: Those of higher perception are virtuous: before enjoying anything they show their gratitude by mentally offering the objects of their enjoyment to the higher powers. Then they partake of them. In this way their individual, confined, ignorant, sinful consciousness is freed from the sense of duality. In contrast, those who are entirely identified with their bodies forget their Creator and the higher powers. They enjoy everything for the sake of their own nourishment and so remain forever ignorant, that is, sinful.

sa:
. अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः ।
यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः ॥
tl: . annādbhavanti bhūtāni parjanyādannasambhavaḥ yajñādbhavati parjanyo yajñaḥ karmasamudbhavaḥ
en:
Without eating food, no being can evolve; so all are dependent upon food. Without rain, food cannot be produced; so food is dependent upon the rain god. Rain falls on account of the spirit of sacrifice dwelling within the sky, clouds, and air; and the spirit of sacrifice with which the wind blows and the rain falls has its origin in the highest Self, God. This can be realized by paying attention to the power of action within man.
In the spirit of sacrifice, which is the creative power, the infinite All-pervading is always present. Therefore, always perform your action with unfailing awareness of the spirit of sacrifice, called yagya.

sa:
कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् ।
तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् ॥
tl:
karma brahmodbhavaṃ viddhi brahmākṣarasamudbhavam
tasmātsarvagataṃ brahma nityaṃ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam
en:
Without eating food, no being can evolve; so all are dependent upon food. Without rain, food cannot be produced; so food is dependent upon the rain god. Rain falls on account of the spirit of sacrifice dwelling within the sky, clouds, and air; and the spirit of sacrifice with which the wind blows and the rain falls has its origin in the highest Self, God. This can be realized by paying attention to the power of action within man.
In the spirit of sacrifice, which is the creative power, the infinite All-pervading is always present. Therefore, always perform your action with unfailing awareness of the spirit of sacrifice, called yagya.

sa:
. एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः ।
अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति ॥
tl:
. evaṃ pravartitaṃ cakraṃ nānuvartayatīha
yaḥ aghāyurindriyārāmo moghaṃ pārtha sa jīvati
en: Arjun, he who does not understand the law of creation, which compels every being to act, becomes influenced by his senses due to his lack of understanding. Unable to reach the goal, he lives in vain.

sa:
. यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः ।
आत्मन्येव च संतुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते ॥
tl:
. yastvātmaratireva syādātmatṛptaśca mānavaḥ ātmanyeva
ca saṃtuṣṭastasya kāryaṃ na vidyate
en: But he who is saturated in the Knowledge of the Self, remaining fully satisfied in the Self, knows that the Self alone is at the back of every action. For such a man there is no special duty to be performed separate from the Self.

sa:
. नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन ।
न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः ॥
tl:
. naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nākṛteneha
kaścana na cāsya sarvabhūteṣu kaścidarthavyapāśrayaḥ
en: One who has realized his Self is as unconcerned with what is happening as with what is yet to happen. He has no selfish and independent identity separate from the Self.  Thus, he is never dependent upon any creature in this world.

sa:
. तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर ।
असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः ॥
tl:
. tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma
samācara asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ
en: Therefore, Arjun, do not entertain the sense of otherness or any attachment to it. Perform your duty well. Working in the light of Awareness of God, man attains the supreme state.

sa:
. कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः ।
लोकसंग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि ॥
tl: . karmaṇaiva hi saṃsiddhimāsthitā janakādayaḥ lokasaṃgrahamevāpi saṃpaśyankartumarhasi
en: Janak and many other wise men reached perfection by performing action without attachment to ego. Since all mankind follows the world order, you too should take to action, performing your duty yet remaining in tune with the Light of God.

sa:
. यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः ।
स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते ॥
tl: . yadyadācarati śreṣṭhastattadevetaro janaḥ sa yatpramāṇaṃ kurute lokastadanuvartate
en: People follow the ideal man: whatever standard of action he originates, they follow. And you, Arjun, are the ideal of everyone.

sa:
. न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किंचन ।
नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि ॥
tl:
. na me pārthāsti kartavyaṃ triṣu
lokeṣu kiṃcana nānavāptamavāptavyaṃ varta eva ca karmaṇi
en: Arjun, in none of the three worlds am I bound by any feeling of need. I have attained everything, so for Me there is no pressure to perform duty for the purpose of gaining something unattained; yet, aware that people will follow the standard I set, I continue to work, for I am the ideal.

sa:
. यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः ।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ॥
tl:
. yadi hyahaṃ na varteyaṃ jātu
karmaṇyatandritaḥ mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
en: If I fail to act with wisdom when it is needed, men will still follow My example, and then this world will suffer great harm.

sa:
. उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम् ।
संकरस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः ॥
tl:
. utsīdeyurime lokā na kuryāṃ karma
cedaham saṃkarasya ca kartā syāmupahanyāmimāḥ prajāḥ
en: If I withdraw My dynamism, not only will these worlds all perish, but, in the process, people will consider Me the cause of their confusion and destruction when they are unable to bring My Light into their minds. It is I who am holding the regulating power of the worlds in perfection, and if I give up this ideal performance of action, then the world, including the people in it, will perish.

sa:
. सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत ।
कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम् ॥
tl: . saktāḥ karmaṇyavidvāṃso yathā kurvanti bhārata kuryādvidvāṃstathāsaktaścikīrṣurlokasaṃgraham
en: Arjun, ignorant men act with duality in their minds, remaining attached to their ignorance yet never ceasing to perform their duty. Similarly, wise men, aware of the necessity of maintaining the world order, should also act, but in the Light of God and without attachment to the ignorance of the mind. Even though they do not gain anything personally from their action, wise men have to continue their work of supporting life.

sa:
. न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम् ।
जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्तः समाचरन् ॥
tl: . na buddhibhedaṃ janayedajñānāṃ karmasaṅginām joṣayetsarvakarmāṇi vidvānyuktaḥ samācaran
en: Arjun, he who is established in the Self should not distract from their duties the minds of those who, while acting, are attached to their sense of ego. He should perform his own duties and encourage the ignorant to perform theirs.

sa:
. प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः ।
अहंकारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते ॥
tl:
. prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ
karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ ahaṃkāravimūḍhātmā kartāhamiti manyate
en: All actions are being performed due to the influence of the gunas, which are the forces of Prakriti, My own nature; but the one who is deluded by the illusory sense of ego concludes that he is the doer.

sa:
. तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः ।
गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्ते इति मत्वा न सज्जते ॥
tl:
. tattvavittu mahābāho guṇakarmavibhāgayoḥ guṇā
guṇeṣu vartante iti matvā na sajjate
en: Arjun, he who knows the respective qualities of the gunas and their power holds firmly in his awareness that it is these gunas, acting and interacting among themselves, which manifest the shapes of objects, bodies, senses, and mind. Such a man does not associate himself with the gunas. He remains the Witness Self, perfectly free from any association or attachment.

sa:
. प्रकृतेर्गुणसंमूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु ।
तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत् ॥
tl: . prakṛterguṇasaṃmūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇakarmasu tānakṛtsnavido mandānkṛtsnavinna vicālayet
en: Those whose minds are completely deluded by the forces of the gunas think themselves influenced by the gunas and their action. Attached to this understanding, such men are bound to act. The man of perfect Knowledge, though he understands this, should not unsettle the minds of such people who have not realized their true nature.

sa:
. मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा ।
निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः ॥
tl:
. mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi
saṃnyasyādhyātmacetasā nirāśīrnirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigatajvaraḥ
en: Arjun, establish yourself in that awareness with which you can dedicate your mind and all your actions to Me, remaining always aware that it is I who am the underlying Self of all that exists. Free from the sense of “mine,” know yourself as Me, the free Being, and use this instrument, the body, to fight. The sense of “mine” is an unnecessary mental fever.

sa:
. ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः ।
श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्तेतेऽपि कर्मभिः ॥
tl:
. ye me matamidaṃ
nityamanutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ śraddhāvanto’nasūyanto mucyantete’pi karmabhiḥ
en: Even though they may not perfectly understand the Truth, those who have faith in My teachings and practice them are released from the sense of ego which binds them to the doership of their actions.

sa:
. ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् ।
सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः ॥
tl: . ye tvetadabhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam sarvajñānavimūḍhāṃstānviddhi naṣṭānacetasaḥ
en: Know that they are deluded fools in the matter of true Knowledge who persist in finding fault with My teachings and do not practice them. They are lost.

sa:
. सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि ।
प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति ॥
tl:
. sadṛśaṃ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛterjñānavānapi
prakṛtiṃ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṃ kariṣyati
en: All beings act according to their natural and habitual tendencies. Even the one who is realized acts according to the habits of his own nature; but by performing godly actions he has elevated his human nature into the Divine, and nobody on earth can stop what he does. Therefore, Arjun, why do you struggle to restrain yourself from acting for the sake of goodness?

sa:
इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ ।
तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ ॥
tl: indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāgadveṣau vyavasthitau tayorna vaśamāgacchettau hyasya paripanthinau
en: Because attraction, raag, and repulsion, dwaysh, are inherent in all the objects of the senses, objects are bound to attract man and to influence him. Since attraction and repulsion are the two chief enemies standing in the way of man’s liberation, he should never allow himself to be carried away by them.

sa:
. श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् ।
स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः ॥
tl:
. śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt
svadharme nidhanaṃ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ
en: One’s own duty is to be performed without hesitation, but one should know that the duty of every man is to act in just such a way that perfection is gained in this lifetime. All other so-called duties are fraught with danger, create fear of further bondage, and ultimately end in no perfection at all. They should not be copied because such duties are paradharm, not swadharm. Performing one’s own true duty, one meets with blessedness, unconcerned even about death. A householder, a recluse, a protector, and a producer of goods all have certain duties; but man’s main duty is to realize his own true nature in this lifetime, no matter what his status. The intelligent man is always aware of how much duty he is compelled to perform. However, he uses skill, or Yog, in performing this action so that even though he is bound and obliged to certain acts by virtue of being a man, his actions bring him blessedness. One’s own swadharm is that means which brings about freedom or liberation from ignorance, the sense of duality.

sa:
. अर्जुन उवाच अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः ।
अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः ॥
tl:
. arjuna uvāca atha kena prayukto’yaṃ
pāpaṃ carati pūruṣaḥ anicchannapi vārṣṇeya balādiva niyojitaḥ
en:
Arjun asked:
Krishn, why does a man act in a way that leads him to suffering? It appears as though he is driven by some force unknown to him.

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः ।
महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम् ॥
tl:
. śrībhagavānuvāca kāma eṣa krodha
eṣa rajoguṇasamudbhavaḥ mahāśano mahāpāpmā viddhyenamiha vairiṇam
en:
Shri Krishn said:
There are definitely certain forces which cause a man to act involuntarily. The force of rajogun creates desire, which makes him act in all kinds of ways, good or bad. The same desire when not fulfilled makes him angry. This desire caused by rajogun is insatiable, utterly wicked, and is to be known as man’s crudest enemy.

sa:
. धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च ।
यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम् ॥
tl: . dhūmenāvriyate vahniryathādarśo malena ca yatholbenāvṛto garbhastathā tenedamāvṛtam
en: As a flame is surrounded by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dirt, as an embryo is enveloped by the womb, similarly is Knowledge obscured by the intense desire born of rajogun. Desire, the sense of duality, covers sattwa, the light and knowledge of Oneness. Thus, the mind becomes deluded.

sa:
. आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा ।
कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च ॥
tl:
. āvṛtaṃ jñānametena jñānino
nityavairiṇā kāmarūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇānalena ca
en: Arjun, this thirst created by desire, or the sense of duality, is so insatiable that it is impossible for anyone to quench it. It is the enemy of the true man of Knowledge.

sa:
. इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते ।
एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम् ॥
tl: . indriyāṇi mano buddhirasyādhiṣṭhānamucyate etairvimohayatyeṣa jñānamāvṛtya dehinam
en: The senses, mind, and intellect are the dwelling places of kaam, desire or anger, which is a form of the ego-being, the sense of duality. This ego-being covers Knowledge by using the mind, intellect, and senses as its tools. Thus, the soul is completely deluded.

sa:
. तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ ।
पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम् ॥
tl: . tasmāttvamindriyāṇyādau niyamya bharatarṣabha pāpmānaṃ prajahi hyenaṃ jñānavijñānanāśanam
en: Arjun, you must eliminate this ego sense which destroys Knowledge, the science of knowing one’s own true nature. To succeed in this you must have full control over your mind, intellect, and senses.

sa:
. इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः ।
मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः ॥
tl:
. indriyāṇi parāṇyāhurindriyebhyaḥ paraṃ manaḥ
manasastu parā buddhiryo buddheḥ paratastu saḥ
en: A definite order is prescribed by which you may reach your true Self. First, do not give importance to the body, for the senses are more powerful; the mind is more powerful than the senses, and the intellect is more powerful than the mind. The Self is the most powerful of all—it is Reality, your own true nature.
