If you know that your own Self is the most powerful, you will always have both the confidence and the ability to control your body, senses, mind, and intellect.

sa:
. एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना ।
जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् ॥
tl:
. evaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā
saṃstabhyātmānamātmanā jahi śatruṃ mahābāho kāmarūpaṃ durāsadam
en:
Thus, having known your own true, infinitely powerful Self, you must use it to control the mind, and with the help of your own intelligence eliminate the sense of duality that makes you forget your true nature. If you do this, you will succeed in eliminating your enemy in the form of ego, or desire.
The chapter known as
KARM YOG
ends.

sa:
श्रीभगवानुवाच इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम् ।
विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् ॥
tl: śrībhagavānuvāca imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave’bravīt
en: It was My first emanation, Vivaswaan, the sun, who was the initial carrier of Yog, the Consciousness of Oneness with Me. He then passed it on to Manu who, as the first man in existence, saw the sun as the first light. Thus, naturally, Manu became the carrier of the sun’s light, which already contained My Yog Consciousness. In his turn, Manu’s son, Ikshwaaku, desiring to know from where that light came, received this information from him.

sa:
. एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः ।
स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परंतप ॥
tl:
. evaṃ paramparāprāptamimaṃ rājarṣayo viduḥ
sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ paraṃtapa
en:
Thus, Arjun, did this Yog, or Knowledge, continue with the dynasty of the sun, for the sun was the first chhatriya, ruler and protector of the whole creation. All who followed him belonged to the sun’s race; and since it was the ruler’s son who was able to grasp the Absolute Knowledge, the original state of Pure Consciousness, he was called Raajarshi. Then, following him, all were raajarshis.
Now the question arises, how was it that this Knowledge could not reach you? The answer is that it disappeared through the passage of time. Forgetfulness takes place in all ages; thus it happened that slowly, slowly, a time came when nobody remembered, and the Knowledge was lost.

sa:
. स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः ।
भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् ॥
tl:
. sa evāyaṃ mayā te’dya yogaḥ proktaḥ
purātanaḥ bhakto’si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṃ hyetaduttamam
en:
Now, I have incarnated with that original Knowledge and am imparting it to you today. No doubt, what I am revealing is secret, but then you deserve to hear it, for you are My devotee and are of the same thought as Myself—you might call it friendship. Since you possess the spirit of self-surrender, you will be able to imbibe this Knowledge. Arjun, you must get over your grief and attain the highest good, which this Knowledge brings about.
Arjun said:

sa:
. अर्जुन उवाच अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः ।
कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति ॥
tl:
. arjuna uvāca aparaṃ bhavato janma
paraṃ janma vivasvataḥ kathametadvijānīyāṃ tvamādau proktavāniti
en:
Krishn, You are present now, whereas King Vivaswaan existed in remote antiquity. How then should I believe that in the beginning of creation, it was You who taught this Yog?
Krishn said:

sa:
श्रीभगवानुवाच बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन ।
तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परंतप ॥
tl:
śrībhagavānuvāca bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna
tānyahaṃ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṃ vettha paraṃtapa
en: Arjun, you do not know, perhaps, that you and I have both passed through many births since then. The reason for your doubt is that you do not remember; whereas, O chastiser of foes, I remember all.

sa:
. अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन् ।
प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया ॥
tl: . ajo’pi sannavyayātmā bhūtānāmīśvaro’pi san prakṛtiṃ svāmadhiṣṭhāya saṃbhavāmyātmamāyayā
en: I am aware of the fact that My real Self is birthless and thus deathless. I am that Self, the Pure Existence which is the beginning of all beings; and I now reveal to you that I manifest Myself through My forces of action and intelligence called Yog Maayaa, the Divine Power. I always remember My true, free, and uninvolved nature as one and one alone manifesting in all the forms of Prakriti.

sa:
. यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत ।
अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम् ॥
tl:
. yadā yadā hi dharmasya
glānirbhavati bhārata abhyutthānamadharmasya tadātmānaṃ sṛjāmyaham
en: Arjun, whenever dharm, the Knowledge of Oneness, declines, then adharm, the sense of duality, increases, becoming so powerful that pain and suffering begin to arise everywhere. At that time, in order to revive the sense of Oneness, I, the Pure Consciousness, manifest Myself in the form of a body and carry that Knowledge with Me.

sa:
. परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम् ।
धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय संभवामि युगे युगे ॥
tl:
. paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṃ vināśāya ca
duṣkṛtām dharmasaṃsthāpanārthāya saṃbhavāmi yuge yuge
en: From age to age I take birth on earth both to protect the dharmwaans who remain in tune with My Vision of Oneness and to remove the sense of duality. It is not that I have to kill those who are dualistic, but I must remove from their minds the forgetfulness that makes them evil-doers. I must re-establish dharm, the Knowledge of Oneness, the Realization of Me who alone am everywhere. Thus it is said that I appear in presence from age to age.

sa:
. जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः ।
त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन ॥
tl:
. janma karma ca me divyamevaṃ yo
vetti tattvataḥ tyaktvā dehaṃ punarjanma naiti māmeti so’rjuna
en: Arjun, the force of action by which I take birth and conduct My activities is extremely fine and cannot be known by those of gross consciousness. As a result of their ignorance, they rotate from birth to birth; but he who knows the divine nature of My birth and activities, knows Me in reality. He stays free from ignorance in this present life knowing that Me here and Me there are one immortal Existence. He remains forever liberated.

sa:
. वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः ।
बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः ॥
tl: . vītarāgabhayakrodhā manmayā māmupāśritāḥ bahavo jñānatapasā pūtā madbhāvamāgatāḥ
en: As drops of water merge once again with the ocean and become one, so, many human beings have become one with Me, their highest Self, when their passion, fear, and anger, all offshoots of the sense of duality, were transformed into the consciousness of self-surrender, or unity.

sa:
. ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम् ।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ॥
tl:
. ye yathā māṃ prapadyante tāṃstathaiva
bhajāmyaham mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
en: Arjun, by whatever path men try to realize their true nature, which is Me, I approach them, because all the paths of consciousness are My paths.

sa:
. काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः ।
क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा ॥
tl:
. kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṃ siddhiṃ yajanta iha
devatāḥ kṣipraṃ hi mānuṣe loke siddhirbhavati karmajā
en: In this world of human beings, people worship the higher powers with a view to successfully gaining the fruits of their activities, such as wife, husband, progeny, wealth, home, honour, name, and fame; and as a result of devoting their activities to the gods, they quickly achieve success. Since the attainment of the highest good in the form of Self Realization takes a long time, men of interested motives act only to satisfy their present desires.

sa:
. चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः ।
तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् ॥
tl:
. cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ
guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam
en: In the world, men are born of the influence of the three gunas as they manifest in the various modes of their mixing. Sattwa is the creator of harmony, rajas is the creator of motion and action, and tamas is the regulator that restrains motion. Based on these gunas, there are four orders of mind, allowing each mind to be classified according to its predominant nature. A man with the first kind of mind is very open to the power that tunes him in to his own Ultimate Truth, and he follows that power for the sake of developing the Knowledge that will guide his life towards immortality. One with the second kind of mind is inclined to support and protect whatever life is already in existence. The third order wants to produce the means of helping that life, and the fourth wants to serve life directly by looking after its needs. According to the inborn qualities existing in a man’s being, his nature unfolds from within to play a definite role through his body. Arjun, since I am at the source of all these orders of consciousness, I call Myself the Creator of these orders; yet, because I simply witness the sport of My creative power, which assumes doership as soon as I manifest it, I say I am forever free and uninvolved, the non-doer.

sa:
. न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा ।
इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते ॥
tl:
. na māṃ karmāṇi limpanti na me
karmaphale spṛhā iti māṃ yo’bhijānāti karmabhirna sa badhyate
en: He who knows Me in this way, as the Being of total freedom and reality, is, like Me, never bound by actions or the fruits thereof.

sa:
. एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः ।
कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम् ॥
tl:
. evaṃ jñātvā kṛtaṃ karma pūrvairapi
mumukṣubhiḥ kuru karmaiva tasmāttvaṃ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṃ kṛtam
en: Having known Me as the free Being, the ancient seekers of liberation performed their actions and were liberated. Arjun, you also should follow the tradition of doing those actions which were performed from the very beginning by your ancestors.

sa:
. किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः ।
तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् ॥
tl:
. kiṃ karma kimakarmeti kavayo’pyatra
mohitāḥ tatte karma pravakṣyāmi yajjñātvā mokṣyase’śubhāt
en: Arjun, it is not only you who are at a loss concerning the nature of action and inaction; even people wiser than you are confused. Therefore, I shall expound the truth about action, knowing which you will be freed from action’s binding nature.

sa:
. कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः ।
अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः ॥
tl:
. karmaṇo hyapi boddhavyaṃ boddhavyaṃ ca
vikarmaṇaḥ akarmaṇaśca boddhavyaṃ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ
en: The truth about action, the truth about prohibited action, and the truth about inaction must be known, Arjun, even though these truths and the ways of action are a mystery.

sa:
. कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः ।
स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् ॥
tl:
. karmaṇyakarma yaḥ paśyedakarmaṇi ca karma
yaḥ sa buddhimānmanuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsnakarmakṛt
en:
He realizes the truth and the ways of action who sees absolute force permeating all action and all action being generated by absolute force, even though that force does not appear to be active. He is a yogi and wise among men who sees this truth of action. He knows that he has attained the perfect Knowledge of performing any action; thus, he is never bound.
The state of perfect Knowledge makes one aware that his traditional knowledge of “I am doing” or “I am the doer” was an incorrect experience. In perfect Knowledge, one grasps that the mental “I” attached to the physical body, senses, things, and works is not the one which has any power of its own to perform action. The “I” belonging to the physical body and circumstances can shine as “I” only when the Pure Light initiates the consciousness of “I.” Arjun, true doership is attributed by men of Realization to that which I am; and that is one with you.
It is because of this that I have been telling you not to hold on to your status as an independent doer, that you should, rather, surrender all your present understanding of doership to Me and know that you are free. It is I who am doing everything. Just be My instrument and agent, and act freely without putting your attention on the achievement of the results of actions performed by your body.

sa:
. यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसंकल्पवर्जिताः ।
ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः ॥
tl:
. yasya sarve samārambhāḥ
kāmasaṃkalpavarjitāḥ jñānāgnidagdhakarmāṇaṃ tamāhuḥ paṇḍitaṃ budhāḥ
en: One is called wise when he knows that his Self is so real and free that no projection of desire, thought, or imagination can affect him. The projections of the past, present, and future are burned by the light and fire of Aatmaa, the Self or God. Aatmaa is the original, absolute fire by whose light the mind shines as human consciousness while it entertains the projections that come to it from the outside world through the medium of the senses. When the projected beams, or waves, of the mind return to the original fire, the absolute sun, they no longer remain as rays of the mind. They are freed from this function. At that time the mind is only the Light of God. One with such a mind is known as a sage.

sa:
. त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः ।
कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किंचित्करोति सः ॥
tl:
. tyaktvā karmaphalāsaṅgaṃ nityatṛpto
nirāśrayaḥ karmaṇyabhipravṛtto’pi naiva kiṃcitkaroti saḥ
en: He who has become totally free from the force of consciousness that creates attachment to things, persons, actions, and their fruits is no longer dependent on the world of things because in him a consciousness of detachment has appeared which keeps him ever satisfied. His force of attachment having been dissolved, he acts in the world, yet is not at all affected by what he does; rather, he is blessed, as if he has done nothing.

sa:
. निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः ।
शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् ॥
tl: . nirāśīryatacittātmā tyaktasarvaparigrahaḥ śārīraṃ kevalaṃ karma kurvannāpnoti kilbiṣam
en: When the power of mind and body that creates attachment no longer remains, the new power that dawns keeps one free from desire and craving. Now when one performs action, he does not become bound by its results.

sa:
. यदृच्छालाभसंतुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः ।
समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते ॥
tl:
. yadṛcchālābhasaṃtuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ samaḥ
siddhāvasiddhau ca kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate
en: When the force of the mind moves from the sphere of attachment into that of contentment, then no matter what is done or received, man remains free from jealousy and the influence of all the pairs of opposites, such as joy and grief, gain and loss, success and failure. He now stays free from the binding influence of those actions which used to affect him when his mind was ruled by attachment to objects and by ignorance of his true nature.

sa:
. गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः ।
यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते ॥
tl: . gatasaṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthitacetasaḥ yajñāyācarataḥ karma samagraṃ pravilīyate
en: He in whose mind the force of attachment has ceased to work, no longer has any ignorant ideas about his being the body, because now there is another force working in his mind’s light—the force of Knowledge. By this force of Knowledge, he remains forever aware that he is not under the sway of his conditioned mind, through which he used to think of himself as an independent doer. Thus, now all his work is done for the sake of the Whole alone.

sa:
. ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् ।
ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना ॥
tl:
. brahmārpaṇaṃ brahma havirbrahmāgnau brahmaṇā
hutam brahmaiva tena gantavyaṃ brahmakarmasamādhinā
en: When the Vision of Brahm lights the mind-space, one sees Brahm everywhere and performs action for the sake of Brahm. When such a one lights the fire into which he will offer food to the higher powers that take care of food and body, then for him, the fire is Brahm, the ladle is Brahm, the oblation is Brahm, and he himself is Brahm. And if he is asked why he is performing this action, he says, “Brahm is the goal.” Thus, the Vision of Oneness with God sees one God everywhere in all His manifestations.

sa:
. दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते ।
ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति ॥
tl: . daivamevāpare yajñaṃ yoginaḥ paryupāsate brahmāgnāvapare yajñaṃ yajñenaivopajuhvati
en: Those who have not attained the Vision of Oneness only worship the gods in the hope of deriving gain. On the other hand, yogis offer their every act to the fire, or Knowledge of God, for they perceive Oneness in identity with God. Although they appear to be the same men they used to be, they now remain free while performing actions.

sa:
. श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति ।
शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति ॥
tl: . śrotrādīnīndriyāṇyanye saṃyamāgniṣu juhvati śabdādīnviṣayānanya indriyāgniṣu juhvati
en: In order to attain the Vision of Oneness, those who are not yogis offer their senses into the fire of self-discipline according to the characteristics of their mental vision.

sa:
. सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे ।
आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते ॥
tl: . sarvāṇīndriyakarmāṇi prāṇakarmāṇi cāpare ātmasaṃyamayogāgnau juhvati jñānadīpite
en: Yogis, when they attain Yog, or the Vision of Oneness, also sacrifice the functioning of their senses and vital forces into the fire of God.

sa:
. द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे ।
स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः ॥
tl: . dravyayajñāstapoyajñā yogayajñāstathāpare svādhyāyajñānayajñāśca yatayaḥ saṃśitavratāḥ
en: Thus, some men perform action to gain material possessions, some practise austerities, some try to attain the power by which they can practise Yog, and some offer their time and energy to the study of sacred texts. All are acting in order to attain Wisdom, the Vision of Oneness.

sa:
. अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे ।
प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः ॥
tl:
. apāne juhvati prāṇaṃ
prāṇe’pānaṃ tathāpare prāṇāpānagatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāmaparāyaṇāḥ
en: There are various practices. Some men practise praanayaam, in which, offering the act of exhalation into the act of inhalation, one gains stability in his breathing and becomes tuned-in to the Vision of Oneness. There are others who regulate their diet and control the involuntary functioning of vital forces, stabilizing them to make the final Vision of Oneness dawn in that luminous sphere of the mind in which one sees God everywhere.

sa:
अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति ।
सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः ॥
tl: apare niyatāhārāḥ prāṇānprāṇeṣu juhvati sarve’pyete yajñavido yajñakṣapitakalmaṣāḥ
en: There are various practices. Some men practise praanayaam, in which, offering the act of exhalation into the act of inhalation, one gains stability in his breathing and becomes tuned-in to the Vision of Oneness. There are others who regulate their diet and control the involuntary functioning of vital forces, stabilizing them to make the final Vision of Oneness dawn in that luminous sphere of the mind in which one sees God everywhere.

sa:
. यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम् ।
नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम ॥
tl:
. yajñaśiṣṭāmṛtabhujo yānti brahma
sanātanam nāyaṃ loko’styayajñasya kuto’nyaḥ kurusattama
en: Arjun, he attains the eternal, Pure Existence who, having burnt all the impressions acquired from without while in the sense of duality, now enjoys the Pure Space left in his head. He who does not burn his impressions, desires, expectations, and hopes in the fire of God remains unhappy in this world.

sa:
. एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे ।
कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे ॥
tl:
. evaṃ bahuvidhā yajñā vitatā
brahmaṇo mukhe karmajānviddhi tānsarvānevaṃ jñātvā vimokṣyase
en: Arjun, many forms of action have been set forth in detail in the scriptures, and ultimately they are all meant for bringing about the Vision of Oneness. Until that Vision appears, these practices keep the mind, senses, and body occupied. Knowing this about scriptural injunctions concerning action, you will not become bound in the following kind of questioning: Why have the scriptures been written in the way they are when it is observed that although many people follow their injunctions, not all of them realize the Vision of Oneness?

sa:
श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परंतप ।
सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते ॥
tl: śreyāndravyamayādyajñājjñānayajñaḥ paraṃtapa sarvaṃ karmākhilaṃ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate
en: Arjun, actions performed in the light of the Knowledge of God as one Reality are superior to those performed in the light of duality consciousness. Actions performed in the Knowledge of God, which is freedom, lead one to freedom, or perfect Knowledge.

sa:
. तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया ।
उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः ॥
tl:
. tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena
sevayā upadekṣyanti te jñānaṃ jñāninastattvadarśinaḥ
en: Arjun, to attain the Knowledge of God, or the Vision of Oneness, one must approach the enlightened ones. If you approach them in a spirit of innocence and with an open heart, those wise seers of the Truth will instruct you in the Knowledge you seek.

sa:
. यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव ।
येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि ॥
tl:
. yajjñātvā na punarmohamevaṃ yāsyasi
pāṇḍava yena bhūtānyaśeṣeṇa drakṣyasyātmanyatho mayi
en: Arjun, when you have reached perfect Enlightenment, no ignorance remains to delude you. When you attain that Knowledge, you will see through your present existence the entire creation and the Creator as one identity. There will be no more division in your consciousness.

sa:
. अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः ।
सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं संतरिष्यसि ॥
tl:
. api cedasi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ
pāpakṛttamaḥ sarvaṃ jñānaplavenaiva vṛjinaṃ saṃtariṣyasi
en: When you have attained this Knowledge, the Vision of Oneness with God, you will be able to act successfully in the world, for this Knowledge will carry you happily through the world as a raft carries one across the ocean.

sa:
. यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन ।
ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा ॥
tl: . yathaidhāṃsi samiddho’gnirbhasmasātkurute’rjuna jñānāgniḥ sarvakarmāṇi bhasmasātkurute tathā
en: Arjun, just as a blazing fire turns fuel to ashes, so the fire of the Knowledge of your Self as one with God turns all your bondage or destined actions to ashes.

sa:
. न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते ।
तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति ॥
tl:
. na hi jñānena sadṛśaṃ
pavitramiha vidyate tatsvayaṃ yogasaṃsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati
en: The Knowledge of your Self as one with God purifies your heart. Then, all action is performed in the Light of Truth, forever.

sa:
. श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः ।
ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्ति- मचिरेणाधिगच्छति ॥
tl:
. śraddhāvā̃llabhate jñānaṃ tatparaḥ saṃyatendriyaḥ
jñānaṃ labdhvā parāṃ śānti- macireṇādhigacchati
en: He who wants to attain this Knowledge must keep his senses under control and, while acting, must maintain full faith that he will attain it. To such a being the Truth reveals itself by itself, and he immediately attains Supreme Peace, the state of Self Realization.

sa:
. अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति ।
नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः ॥
tl:
. ajñaścāśraddadhānaśca saṃśayātmā vinaśyati nāyaṃ
loko’sti na paro na sukhaṃ saṃśayātmanaḥ
en: He cannot follow the spiritual path who is unable to discriminate between pain and happiness and who, possessed by scepticism and doubt, has no faith in his power to attain Self Realization. For such a doubting person there can be no happiness at all.

sa:
. योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसंछिन्नसंशयम् ।
आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनंजय ॥
tl: . yogasaṃnyastakarmāṇaṃ jñānasaṃchinnasaṃśayam ātmavantaṃ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanaṃjaya
en: Arjun, when the Light of the Self has begun to permeate the light of the individual consciousness, the human mind, one does not become bound by one’s actions. In the spirit of God’s Light, one is no longer a doer for he has dedicated his sense of doership to his highest Self, God. In his mind there is no doubt at all. Only the Light of Wisdom shines constantly.

sa:
. तस्मादज्ञानसंभूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः ।
छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत ॥
tl: . tasmādajñānasaṃbhūtaṃ hṛtsthaṃ jñānāsinātmanaḥ chittvainaṃ saṃśayaṃ yogamātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata
en:
Therefore, Arjun, take up the sword of Wisdom which slashes doubt to pieces; and having grasped it, stand up and fight. You will remain forever balanced and even-tempered because ignorance will never enter your heart. Once you have attained this Wisdom, your actions will be regulated in such a manner that you remain forever free while performing action. The technique is called Karm Yog. It keeps one free from ignorance of one’s true nature, and it allows one to perform action in freedom.
The chapter known as
GYAAN KARM SANNYAAS YOG
ends.

sa:
अर्जुन उवाच संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि ।
यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम् ॥
tl:
arjuna uvāca saṃnyāsaṃ karmaṇāṃ kṛṣṇa punaryogaṃ
ca śaṃsasi yacchreya etayorekaṃ tanme brūhi suniścitam
en:
Krishn, You speak of the Yog of Knowledge and the Yog of Action. Please tell me which of the two is the better.
Shri Krishn said:

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ ।
तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते ॥
tl: . śrībhagavānuvāca saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate
en: The Yog of Knowledge and the Yog of Action both lead the mind towards the attainment of Supreme Bliss. Because the teachings regarding action can be easily practised, and because, for the most part, man is not capable of grasping the Yog based on Knowledge, the Yog of Action is considered to be better for mankind in general.

sa:
. ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति ।
निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते ॥
tl:
. jñeyaḥ sa nityasaṃnyāsī yo na dveṣṭi
na kāṅkṣati nirdvandvo hi mahābāho sukhaṃ bandhātpramucyate
en: That yogi who has transcended mental consciousness, the quality of which is to prompt one either to desire a thing or to recoil from it, is considered a sannyaasi, a renunciate. He is forever free. He who while performing action is unaffected by the good and bad of the struggling consciousness is also considered to be free from bondage. He is uninfluenced by the effects of the pairs of opposites and is not bound by the idea of gain and loss.

sa:
. सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः ।
एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् ॥
tl:
. sāṃkhyayogau pṛthagbālāḥ pravadanti
na paṇḍitāḥ ekamapyāsthitaḥ samyagubhayorvindate phalam
en: Arjun, it is the limited understanding of certain men which makes them say that Saankhya Yog and the teachings based on action yield different results. He whose consciousness is firmly established in either of the two attains the fruit of both, which is God Realization. He is wise.

sa:
. यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते ।
एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति ॥
tl:
. yatsāṃkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṃ tadyogairapi gamyate ekaṃ
sāṃkhyaṃ ca yogaṃ ca yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati
en: The perfection reached by the follower of Saankhya Yog, the Path of Study, is the same as that attained by the follower of Karm Yog, the Path of Action. Therefore, he is the real seer who sees the result obtained through either Saankhya or Karm Yog as one and the same, that is, Self Realization.

sa:
. संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः ।
योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति ॥
tl: . saṃnyāsastu mahābāho duḥkhamāptumayogataḥ yogayukto munirbrahma nacireṇādhigacchati
en: The renunciation of doership, which is considered to be attained by following the Path of Knowledge, cannot be tested without the performance of action. Thus, the Path of Knowledge alone is not enough; the performance of action is a must. And if the karm yogi, the follower of action, performs action without the knowledge of how to keep his mind fixed on God, that also is not enough. Therefore, in order to reach the state of Self Realization, one must maintain the unity of Gyaan and Karm, Knowledge and Action. This will bring success in no time.

sa:
. योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः ।
सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते ॥
tl:
. yogayukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā
jitendriyaḥ sarvabhūtātmabhūtātmā kurvannapi na lipyate
en: A person who has attained the power in his self to conquer the desires and modifications of his mind is never defeated by his mind and senses. He is the master because he has identified himself with his own Lord, the Self of all beings. He remains uninvolved and free even while performing actions through his now fully conquered mind and senses, for he is no longer a doer.

sa:
. नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् ।
पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपञ्श्वसन् ॥
tl: . naiva kiṃcitkaromīti yukto manyeta tattvavit paśyañśṛṇvanspṛśañjighrannaśnangacchansvapañśvasan
en: One who knows the reality of his own Self and the Self of the world knows that the Self is the ultimate ground of existence and is the non-doer. He as the Pure Self-Being, does nothing. Even while perceiving, seeing, hearing, speaking, smelling, touching, holding, eating, drinking, walking, sleeping, breathing, opening or closing the eyes, and answering the calls of nature, he remains constantly aware that all this is just the senses busy among their objects and that he is all of these happenings.

sa:
प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् ॥
tl: pralapanvisṛjangṛhṇannunmiṣannimiṣannapi indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣu vartanta iti dhārayan
en: One who knows the reality of his own Self and the Self of the world knows that the Self is the ultimate ground of existence and is the non-doer. He as the Pure Self-Being, does nothing. Even while perceiving, seeing, hearing, speaking, smelling, touching, holding, eating, drinking, walking, sleeping, breathing, opening or closing the eyes, and answering the calls of nature, he remains constantly aware that all this is just the senses busy among their objects and that he is all of these happenings.

sa:
. ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः ।
लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा ॥
tl:
. brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti
yaḥ lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā
en: He who has gained that consciousness in which he surrenders all actions to God, the Self, has shaken off attachment-consciousness, in the light of which he used to know himself as the doer. Now, one with God, he is as unaffected by the thought of doership as a lotus leaf by water.

sa:
. कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि ।
योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये ॥
tl:
. kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalairindriyairapi
yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṃ tyaktvātmaśuddhaye
en: He is not involved at all who, performing action with the help of his senses, mind, intellect, and body, maintains the knowledge that it is these vehicles alone which are acting. He is the real karm yogi whose every action brings him closer to the attainment of God Consciousness.

sa:
. युक्तः कर्मफलंत्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम् ।
अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते ॥
tl:
. yuktaḥ karmaphalaṃtyaktvā śāntimāpnoti naiṣṭhikīm
ayuktaḥ kāmakāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate
en: He who holds to the knowledge of offering the fruits of action to God attains everlasting peace in the form of God Consciousness. On the other hand, he who, due to desire and selfishness, remains attached to the results of his actions becomes bound by those results.

sa:
. सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी ।
नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् ॥
tl:
. sarvakarmāṇi manasā saṃnyasyāste sukhaṃ vaśī
navadvāre pure dehī naiva kurvanna kārayan
en: Dedicating to God the sense of doership regarding the actions performed by his senses and body, the Self-realized yogi rests happily in God Consciousness.

sa:
. न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः ।
न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते ॥
tl:
. na kartṛtvaṃ na karmāṇi lokasya
sṛjati prabhuḥ na karmaphalasaṃyogaṃ svabhāvastu pravartate
en: The Self is forever free and uninvolved; yet this very Self creates the world using the power emanating out of Himself as His creative force, or nature. Thus, He is referred to as both uninvolved and the Creator; and doership, action, and the experience of the fruits of action are said to belong to His nature alone.

sa:
. नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः ।
अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः ॥
tl:
. nādatte kasyacitpāpaṃ na caiva sukṛtaṃ
vibhuḥ ajñānenāvṛtaṃ jñānaṃ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
en: Omnipresent, Absolute God is not involved in receiving anyone’s virtuous or unvirtuous offerings. It is those beings whose consciousness is enveloped in ignorance who fall prey to delusion and become bound by the results of their actions.

sa:
. ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः ।
तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ॥
tl:
. jñānena tu tadajñānaṃ
yeṣāṃ nāśitamātmanaḥ teṣāmādityavajjñānaṃ prakāśayati tatparam
en: He in whom God Consciousness has appeared comes to grasp the true nature of the Supreme Being as ultimate freedom, just as when the sun rises one comes to see everything clearly in the light of day.

sa:
. तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः ।
गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः ॥
tl: . tadbuddhayastadātmānastanniṣṭhāstatparāyaṇāḥ gacchantyapunarāvṛttiṃ jñānanirdhūtakalmaṣāḥ
en: Those whose minds and intellects have merged with the Light of God remain constantly established in identity with the Self and become one with the Lord. Reaching this state of Consciousness, they can never again become ignorant of their true nature.

sa:
. विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि ।
शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ॥
tl:
. vidyāvinayasaṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
śuni caiva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ samadarśinaḥ
en: He who has become one with God comes to know that it is God alone who is manifesting as all forms, whether as man, cow, elephant, or dog. His vision recognizes Oneness with all in whatever he sees.

sa:
. इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः ।
निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः ॥
tl:
. ihaiva tairjitaḥ sargo yeṣāṃ sāmye sthitaṃ
manaḥ nirdoṣaṃ hi samaṃ brahma tasmādbrahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
en: Those who attain unity of consciousness with God are said to have conquered this mortal plane of existence. Since the Absolute is untouched by the motion of its waves, those who become established in Absolute Consciousness attain its nature and are untouched by the turmoil of the world.

sa:
. न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम् ।
स्थिरबुद्धिरसंमूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः ॥
tl:
. na prahṛṣyetpriyaṃ prāpya
nodvijetprāpya cāpriyam sthirabuddhirasaṃmūḍho brahmavidbrahmaṇi sthitaḥ
en: The knower of Brahm, which is the Self, lives eternally in identity with Brahm. Unaffected either by what is pleasant or by what is unpleasant, he remains forever free, even though he still knows what is pleasant and what is unpleasant.

sa:
. बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम् ।
स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते ॥
tl: . bāhyasparśeṣvasaktātmā vindatyātmani yatsukham sa brahmayogayuktātmā sukhamakṣayamaśnute
en: He who has attained this detached state of consciousness holds his resultant joy under all circumstances, while dealing with every situation and happening. Acting thus in the world, in due course of time he attains the Consciousness of Oneness with God, which is absolute joy.

sa:
. ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते ।
आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः ॥
tl:
. ye hi saṃsparśajā bhogā duḥkhayonaya eva
te ādyantavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ
en: When one is in the attached state of consciousness, he will always suffer in the experience of pleasure because pleasure, born of sense contacts, has a beginning and an end. Therefore, Arjun, you should know that an intelligent man, realizing this fact will not with attachment indulge in pleasure. He tries to transcend the sense of duality.

sa:
. शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात् ।
कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः ॥
tl:
. śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṃ prākśarīravimokṣaṇāt kāmakrodhodbhavaṃ
vegaṃ sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ
en: The yogi is he who has conquered the urges of lust and anger; thus, he alone is a happy man. Throughout his life he lives in freedom because he has attained joyful consciousness in his individual sense, the mind.

sa:
. योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः ।
स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति ॥
tl: . yo’ntaḥsukho’ntarārāmastathāntarjyotireva yaḥ sa yogī brahmanirvāṇaṃ brahmabhūto’dhigacchati
en: He who has attained the consciousness of inner happiness enjoys the Bliss of the Absolute and remains aware of his own true nature. Such a yogi, identified with Brahm, God, is said to have attained God or to have realized his own Self, the nature of which is all peace.

sa:
. लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः ।
छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः ॥
tl: . labhante brahmanirvāṇamṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇakalmaṣāḥ chinnadvaidhā yatātmānaḥ sarvabhūtahite ratāḥ
en: Those who have become liberated from their ignorance are definite about the Reality. While their attention remains fixed at the centre, the source of all creation, their joy lies in helping all the beings of the world. Such God-realized ones are said to have attained the peace of the Absolute.

sa:
. कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम् ।
अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम् ॥
tl: . kāmakrodhaviyuktānāṃ yatīnāṃ yatacetasām abhito brahmanirvāṇaṃ vartate viditātmanām
en: Those who have realized the Self, Brahm or God, are free from attachment and anger. Their minds are under control, and at all times they know that God is the sole Reality.

sa:
. स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः ।
प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ ॥
tl: . sparśānkṛtvā bahirbāhyāṃścakṣuścaivāntare bhruvoḥ prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā nāsābhyantaracāriṇau
en: Here is the technique for bringing the mind and intellect under control: With the eyes closed one should gaze at the space between the eyebrows and very carefully regulate the outgoing praan and ingoing apaan breaths, which should be made to flow through the nostrils. One should be neutral to all thoughts of external or internal enjoyment. If he uses this technique, the meditative soul will develop the power to control his senses and mind; this will make him free from desire, fear, and anger. He will be liberated forever from the binding effects of the senses.

sa:
यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः ।
विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः ॥
tl: yatendriyamanobuddhirmunirmokṣaparāyaṇaḥ vigatecchābhayakrodho yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ
en: Here is the technique for bringing the mind and intellect under control: With the eyes closed one should gaze at the space between the eyebrows and very carefully regulate the outgoing praan and ingoing apaan breaths, which should be made to flow through the nostrils. One should be neutral to all thoughts of external or internal enjoyment. If he uses this technique, the meditative soul will develop the power to control his senses and mind; this will make him free from desire, fear, and anger. He will be liberated forever from the binding effects of the senses.

sa:
. भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् ।
सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति ॥
tl:
. bhoktāraṃ yajñatapasāṃ sarvalokamaheśvaram
suhṛdaṃ sarvabhūtānāṃ jñātvā māṃ śāntimṛcchati
en:
That devotee of Mine who has really known Me as the Ultimate Reality, forever free and uninvolved, the Supreme Being of all the worlds, attains peace as his consciousness becomes one with Me in its identity.
The chapter known as
KARM SANNYAAS YOG
ends.

sa:
श्रीभगवानुवाच अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः ।
स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः ॥
tl:
śrībhagavānuvāca anāśritaḥ karmaphalaṃ kāryaṃ karma karoti yaḥ
sa saṃnyāsī ca yogī ca na niragnirna cākriyaḥ
en:
He who performs his duty without depending upon the fruits of his action is called a sannyaasi or a saankhya yogi, a man of Knowledge. He is sure that action well-performed will result in success. He is aware that action and its results belong to God, so he depends only on God, who gives him the inspiration and strength to act. Thus, he is a karm yogi as well, for in his consciousness his ego has been surrendered to God.
On the other hand, one who has given up the Knowledge that all belongs to God is not a sannyaasi, a saankhya yogi, or a karm yogi, even though he may have given up everything including action, because in his very giving up, the sense of ego by which he knows himself to be the doer of his renunciation remains intact.

sa:
. यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव ।
न ह्यसंन्यस्तसंकल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन ॥
tl:
. yaṃ saṃnyāsamiti prāhuryogaṃ taṃ viddhi
pāṇḍava na hyasaṃnyastasaṃkalpo yogī bhavati kaścana
en: Arjun, sannyaas, or renunciation, and Yog are the same state because both lead one to transcend the sense of duality, the consciousness of ego.

sa:
. आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते ।
योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते ॥
tl: . ārurukṣormuneryogaṃ karma kāraṇamucyate yogārūḍhasya tasyaiva śamaḥ kāraṇamucyate
en: For one who has become aware of freedom, the highest Yog Consciousness, action is the first step towards its attainment. Having devoted time to the action of meditation, one becomes established in the state of Unity Consciousness and gains that nature of his awareness which allows him to be in blessedness, in which there remains no sense of division or thought of the world as separate from the Whole.

sa:
. यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते ।
सर्वसंकल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते ॥
tl: . yadā hi nendriyārtheṣu na karmasvanuṣajjate sarvasaṃkalpasaṃnyāsī yogārūḍhastadocyate
en: When a man transcends attachment, whether to the objects of the senses or to action, he is said to have attained the state of perfect Yog in which the sense of the world is dissolved entirely. This state is utterly unlike the imperfect consciousness of a person who sees the world as separate from the Whole.

sa:
. उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् ।
आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः ॥
tl: . uddharedātmanātmānaṃ nātmānamavasādayet ātmaiva hyātmano bandhurātmaiva ripurātmanaḥ
en: One should raise his lower self with the help of his friendly, higher Self. He should not denounce or degrade himself under any circumstances, for his very Self is his own friend or enemy.

sa:
. बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः ।
अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत् ॥
tl: . bandhurātmātmanastasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ anātmanastu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatruvat
en: For him who has transcended the consciousness which keeps him attached to the mind, senses, and body, his Self is a friend. On the other hand, for one whose attachment to the body remains intact, his Self behaves like an enemy.

sa:
. जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः ।
शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः ॥
tl: . jitātmanaḥ praśāntasya paramātmā samāhitaḥ śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkheṣu tathā mānāpamānayoḥ
en: One who has attained the consciousness which maintains serenity in the midst of the pairs of opposites, such as heat and cold, joy and sorrow, honour and dishonour, reaches the Supreme Spirit, Sat-Chit-Aanand. Undisturbed by any circumstance, he is forever at peace.

sa:
. ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः ।
युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः ॥
tl: . jñānavijñānatṛptātmā kūṭastho vijitendriyaḥ yukta ityucyate yogī samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ
en: The yogi who holds in his awareness that Absolute Brahm without form and Brahm with form are one and the same is the master of his senses. He is unmoved under all circumstances. In his vision, earth, stone, and gold are manifestations of the one Being permeating them all. That yogi is said to be a God-realized being.

sa:
. सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीन मध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु ।
साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते ॥
tl: . suhṛnmitrāryudāsīna madhyasthadveṣyabandhuṣu sādhuṣvapi ca pāpeṣu samabuddhirviśiṣyate
en: One who has become aware that there is only one Vision and who, with that Vision of Oneness, looks upon well-wishers, mediators, relatives, friends, foes, the unbiased, the virtuous, and the sinful alike stands supreme. He is unique because he knows that all these are various states of consciousness manifesting out of the same Supreme Being.

sa:
. योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः ।
एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः ॥
tl:
. yogī yuñjīta satatamātmānaṃ
rahasi sthitaḥ ekākī yatacittātmā nirāśīraparigrahaḥ
en: One who has become united with God Consciousness, who has gained control of his mind, body, and senses by merging them into God Consciousness, and who is free from the sense of duality and possession should, in seclusion, constantly engage his awareness in watchfulness. In this way he will acquire a clear knowledge of what the mind is when it arises. He will know that he is the watcher before the mind arises, when it is about to arise, and when it has arisen.

sa:
. शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः ।
नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम् ॥
tl: . śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiramāsanamātmanaḥ nātyucchritaṃ nātinīcaṃ cailājinakuśottaram
en: This is the arrangement devised for meditation: First, the yogi should set up a firm seat in a clean spot. This seat should be comfortable enough so as not to cause any uneasiness for him while he sits. It should be neither very high nor very low. Second, the yogi should sit with his spine straight and begin to watch the mind and its waves as they arise. His attention should always rest on the source of thinking, the Pure Space within his head. It should stay concentrated on this Space, and the yogi should not care about what is taking place with the mind and senses. He should sit in the practice of Meditation Yog like a perfect master who is never affected or disturbed by the atmosphere around him. Thus, daily he will expand his present level of consciousness.

sa:
तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः ।
उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये ॥
tl: tatraikāgraṃ manaḥ kṛtvā yatacittendriyakriyaḥ upaviśyāsane yuñjyādyogamātmaviśuddhaye
en: This is the arrangement devised for meditation: First, the yogi should set up a firm seat in a clean spot. This seat should be comfortable enough so as not to cause any uneasiness for him while he sits. It should be neither very high nor very low. Second, the yogi should sit with his spine straight and begin to watch the mind and its waves as they arise. His attention should always rest on the source of thinking, the Pure Space within his head. It should stay concentrated on this Space, and the yogi should not care about what is taking place with the mind and senses. He should sit in the practice of Meditation Yog like a perfect master who is never affected or disturbed by the atmosphere around him. Thus, daily he will expand his present level of consciousness.

sa:
समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः ।
संप्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन् ॥
tl: samaṃ kāyaśirogrīvaṃ dhārayannacalaṃ sthiraḥ saṃprekṣya nāsikāgraṃ svaṃ diśaścānavalokayan
en: While meditating, the trunk, head, and neck should be held unvaryingly straight and steady. The eyes should be closed while the inner vision, to keep it undistracted, should be focussed on the centre of the space twelve inches in front of the bridge of the nose.

sa:
. प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः ।
मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः ॥
tl:
. praśāntātmā vigatabhīrbrahmacārivrate sthitaḥ manaḥ
saṃyamya maccitto yukta āsīta matparaḥ
en: The yogi should remain aware of the fact that he is meditating on the Self. The Self is the very existence of Pure Consciousness, the perfect Bliss out of which all the inner and outer forces initiate their functions at every level in the universe. One should remain firm and regular, calm and fearless while practising meditation, and should not allow himself to slip in his vigilance.

sa:
. युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः ।
शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति ॥
tl: . yuñjannevaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī niyatamānasaḥ śāntiṃ nirvāṇaparamāṃ matsaṃsthāmadhigacchati
en: Thus, the yogi should remain constantly aware of Me, the Ultimate Existence, Pure Consciousness, and Bliss. If he becomes well-versed in this technique and disciplined in its practice, he will attain everlasting peace, the Supreme Bliss abiding in Me alone. For, when his consciousness becomes one with Me, he will enjoy the qualities and values of Sat-Chit-Aanand on the level of his body, mind, and senses, which will all be permeated by My true, blessed nature.

sa:
. नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः ।
न चाति स्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन ॥
tl:
. nātyaśnatastu yogo’sti na caikāntamanaśnataḥ
na cāti svapnaśīlasya jāgrato naiva cārjuna
en: Arjun, unity with God can be attained neither by one who overeats, nor by one who does not eat at all; it cannot be attained by one who sleeps too much or by one who remains ceaselessly awake.

sa:
. युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु ।
युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा ॥
tl: . yuktāhāravihārasya yuktaceṣṭasya karmasu yuktasvapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkhahā
en: This state of Yog with God frees one from all the troubles of the world and is attained only by one who regulates his diet, recreation, performance of good actions, sleep, and wakefulness. In other words, only one who is balanced in every walk of life and regular in his practice of meditation quickly attains the Consciousness of unity with God.

sa:
. यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते ।
निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा ॥
tl:
. yadā viniyataṃ cittamātmanyevāvatiṣṭhate
niḥspṛhaḥ sarvakāmebhyo yukta ityucyate tadā
en: When the attention has been thoroughly cultured, it is easily merged with God’s Consciousness. Having transformed his individual consciousness into God, one is free from imperfection and does not hanker for sense enjoyments. Such a man is said to be established in the Vision of Oneness, or Yog.

sa:
. यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता ।
योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः ॥
tl:
. yathā dīpo nivātastho neṅgate
sopamā smṛtā yogino yatacittasya yuñjato yogamātmanaḥ
en: The consciousness of the yogi practising the Yog of Meditation, in which he is aware of his own true nature, is perfectly placid and serene. It is like a candle flame, unflickering in a windless place.

sa:
. यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया ।
यत्र चैवात्मनात्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति ॥
tl:
. yatroparamate cittaṃ niruddhaṃ
yogasevayā yatra caivātmanātmānaṃ paśyannātmani tuṣyati
en: The quality of that state of consciousness which has become one with God through the practice of meditation is such that the mind remains serene, calm, still, yet full of power to act in the world. In this state the individual soul, which is the basis of human existence, rejoices only in the Knowledge of God.

sa:
. सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् ।
वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः ॥
tl:
. sukhamātyantikaṃ yattadbuddhigrāhyamatīndriyam vetti
yatra na caivāyaṃ sthitaścalati tattvataḥ
en: In the state of God Consciousness, the soul, the individual human being, experiences that eternal joy which can be grasped only by the most subtle, purified, and expanded intellect. Once the yogi is established in this state of unity with God, he never on any account moves away from Truth.

sa:
. यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः ।
यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते ॥
tl:
. yaṃ labdhvā cāparaṃ lābhaṃ manyate
nādhikaṃ tataḥ yasminsthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vicālyate
en: Arjun, having obtained God Consciousness, the yogi does not consider that any gain on earth could be greater. Established in this state, he is shaken neither by sorrow nor by the greatest pain.

sa:
. तं विद्याद्दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम् ।
स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा ॥
tl: . taṃ vidyādduḥkhasaṃyogaviyogaṃ yogasaṃjñitam sa niścayena yoktavyo yogo’nirviṇṇacetasā
en: Arjun, God Consciousness, the state of Yog, is the only state of consciousness with the power to free man from the contact with sorrow which takes place naturally due to the idea of birth and death. Therefore, practice for the attainment of this state should be resolutely undertaken without any hesitation in the mind. This state must be realized.

sa:
. संकल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः ।
मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः ॥
tl: . saṃkalpaprabhavānkāmāṃstyaktvā sarvānaśeṣataḥ manasaivendriyagrāmaṃ viniyamya samantataḥ
en: While practising, one should not give the sense of duality any importance. All desires appearing on this level should be treated lightly. One should not pay attention to the functioning of the senses during the period of meditation. One should sit in meditation as a master.

sa:
. शनैः शनैरुपरमेत् बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया ।
आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किंचिदपि चिन्तयेत् ॥
tl:
. śanaiḥ śanairuparamet buddhyā dhṛtigṛhītayā
ātmasaṃsthaṃ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiṃcidapi cintayet
en: The yogi should remain aware throughout his practice and should keep watching as tranquillity gradually manifests in his consciousness. He should always make use of his power of reasoning to help him fix his attention on the field of Pure Consciousness from which all powers emanate. The field of Pure Consciousness is immortal and blissful; in Sanskrit, amaram madhuram. These words are a mantr which the yogi can use in his meditation. Focussing his attention on their sound, identifying with the Knower as himself, the utterance as his own creation, and the attention as his own faculty of perception, he realizes that it is He Himself who alone exists as the one Lord of Pure Consciousness, Existence, and Bliss. If this realization of his own true Self takes place, he grasps the meaning of My words, which is that the body is simply an instrument which will perish and is not the Lord, the Seer, or the Knower. This is the practice one is advised to adopt while meditating on Me, the immortal, blissful Supreme Being. During meditation, all the experiences taking place should be treated as manifest waves of the absolute Pure Existence, which is God.

sa:
. यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम् ।
ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत् ॥
tl:
. yato yato niścarati
manaścañcalamasthiram tatastato niyamyaitadātmanyeva vaśaṃ nayet
en: In the beginning, while practising according to one’s own perceptive mechanism, one may observe that the waves of his mind are running after objects, plans, or persons. At that time, he should not create an idea that he is being disturbed; rather, he should use the faculty of the friendly Self and again and again fix his attention on the absolute field of Existence from which all thoughts are coming. Treating thoughts as the play of the force of Consciousness, he should never make any effort to stop them because just by fixing his attention on the source, the yogi’s consciousness merges with God and he knows that the whole of existence is one Reality.

sa:
. प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम् ।
उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम् ॥
tl: . praśāntamanasaṃ hyenaṃ yoginaṃ sukhamuttamam upaiti śāntarajasaṃ brahmabhūtamakalmaṣam
en: When the yogi reaches the state in which he merges in identity with God, his mind automatically imbibes all the qualities of Brahm: Truth, Knowledge, and Bliss. Then, unbroken happiness is attained as a matter of course.

sa:
. युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः ।
सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते ॥
tl: . yuñjannevaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī vigatakalmaṣaḥ sukhena brahmasaṃsparśamatyantaṃ sukhamaśnute
en: The yogi whose previously individual consciousness has become united in identity with Brahm easily enjoys the eternal Bliss which results from the attainment of Oneness with God.

sa:
. सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि ।
ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः ॥
tl: . sarvabhūtasthamātmānaṃ sarvabhūtāni cātmani īkṣate yogayuktātmā sarvatra samadarśanaḥ
en: With his vision transformed into Unity, he who has become identified with infinite Consciousness, the field of all-pervading Pure Existence, now sees his own Self in identity with the Whole and permeating all beings. He watches all beings as manifest happenings in the one Self, and remains aware that the force of Consciousness by which he knows all beings everywhere as the one Self is also a manifestation of that same Self.

sa:
. यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति ।
तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति ॥
tl:
. yo māṃ paśyati sarvatra sarvaṃ ca mayi
paśyati tasyāhaṃ na praṇaśyāmi sa ca me na praṇaśyati
en: Arjun, he who has gained this ability to see Me, the universal Self, permeating all beings, and all existing being as My own forms dwelling within Me, never loses sight of Me and so becomes one with Me. And I never lose sight of him, for this Vision is one and the same everywhere in all forms. Thus, he never separates Me from him, or him from Me, or all from Me and him.

sa:
. सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः ।
सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते ॥
tl:
. sarvabhūtasthitaṃ yo māṃ bhajatyekatvamāsthitaḥ
sarvathā vartamāno’pi sa yogī mayi vartate
en: Established in union with My Vision, he knows I am residing in all beings as their true Existence. He then constantly abides in Me even while his body, mind, and senses are engaged in the world. In fact, his body should no longer be called his own.

sa:
. आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन ।
सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं स योगी परमो मतः ॥
tl:
. ātmaupamyena sarvatra samaṃ paśyati yo’rjuna sukhaṃ
vā yadi vā duḥkhaṃ sa yogī paramo mataḥ
en:
Arjun, one who looks upon all as Me, just as a human being looks upon his limbs, organs, and senses as himself, understands the joy and sorrow of all with sympathetic vision, and uses his body to help all who deserve his attention. I deem such a yogi the highest of all who has attained this philosophic maturity of vision and retains it throughout.
Arjun said:

sa:
. अर्जुन उवाच योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन ।
एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात्स्थितिं स्थिराम् ॥
tl:
. arjuna uvāca yo’yaṃ yogastvayā proktaḥ
sāmyena madhusūdana etasyāhaṃ na paśyāmi cañcalatvātsthitiṃ sthirām
en: Krishn, in my present state of mind I cannot conceive that this state of Yog Consciousness will ever find stability in me. You have spoken about it to me and I have heard You, but because of my mind’s unsteadiness, I do not think it is possible for me.

sa:
. चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम् ।
तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम् ॥
tl:
. cañcalaṃ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi
balavaddṛḍham tasyāhaṃ nigrahaṃ manye vāyoriva suduṣkaram
en:
I am aware of this mind, Krishn, which is unsteady, turbulent, powerful, and tenacious in the pursuit of its ways. I am aware that it is as difficult to control as the wind.
Krishn said:

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलम् ।
अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते ॥
tl:
. śrībhagavānuvāca asaṃśayaṃ mahābāho mano durnigrahaṃ
calam abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate
en: Arjun, it has doubtless been observed that this mind is restless and difficult to control, but it can certainly be transformed into another dimension by the repeated practice of meditation and by continued awareness that there is no separation of anything from Me. Then, the so-called unsteady mind can be used with perfect mastery. I shower My executive power on one with such a mind.

sa:
. असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः ।
वश्यात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः ॥
tl:
. asaṃyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti
me matiḥ vaśyātmanā tu yatatā śakyo’vāptumupāyataḥ
en:
Arjun, for those who treat the mind and its ways as a reality separate from Me, the attainment of the Consciousness of unity with Me is difficult. But this state of blessedness called the controlled mind can easily be attained by those who have grasped these teachings and techniques and who practise them ceaselessly in their lives. This is My conviction.
Arjun asked:

sa:
. अर्जुन उवाच अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः ।
अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति ॥
tl:
. arjuna uvāca ayatiḥ śraddhayopeto yogāccalitamānasaḥ
aprāpya yogasaṃsiddhiṃ kāṃ gatiṃ kṛṣṇa gacchati
en: Tell me, Krishn, after his death, what becomes of that individual who, though full of faith, could not attain the God-realized state of Yog due to the unsteadiness of his mind?

sa:
कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति ।
अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि ॥
tl: kaccinnobhayavibhraṣṭaśchinnābhramiva naśyati apratiṣṭho mahābāho vimūḍho brahmaṇaḥ pathi
en: Unable to lead himself along the path of God Realization and stay on it, and having failed to realize God Consciousness and experience heavenly joy, is he not lost like a torn cloud?

sa:
एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः ।
त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते ॥
tl:
etanme saṃśayaṃ kṛṣṇa chettumarhasyaśeṣataḥ
tvadanyaḥ saṃśayasyāsya chettā na hyupapadyate
en:
Krishn, I am a little doubtful and You are the only one capable of removing my doubt. Please do so.
Shri Krishn replied:

sa:
. श्रीभगवानुवाच पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते ।
न हि कल्याणकृत्कश्चिद्दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति ॥
tl:
. śrībhagavānuvāca pārtha naiveha nāmutra vināśastasya
vidyate na hi kalyāṇakṛtkaściddurgatiṃ tāta gacchati
en: O Arjun, one who starts on the path and strives for God Realization never falls below the state of consciousness he attains in this life. He meets no evil destiny either here or hereafter.

sa:
. प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोका- नुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः ।
शुचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते ॥
tl:
. prāpya puṇyakṛtāṃ lokā- nuṣitvā
śāśvatīḥ samāḥ śucīnāṃ śrīmatāṃ gehe yogabhraṣṭo’bhijāyate
en: Arjun, he who is unable to reach the perfect Realization of God in this lifetime attains the higher worlds inhabited by those who performed meritorious deeds while on earth. He lives happily in those worlds for countless years and, afterwards, again takes birth on earth, this time in the home of a good and wealthy man.

sa:
. अथवा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम् ।
एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम् ॥
tl:
. athavā yogināmeva kule bhavati
dhīmatām etaddhi durlabhataraṃ loke janma yadīdṛśam
en: If a man reaches the Vision of Oneness but dies unable to retain it in its fullness, he is born into a family of enlightened yogis or realized ones; but it is very rare to obtain such a birth in this world.

sa:
. तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम् ।
यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन ॥
tl:
. tatra taṃ buddhisaṃyogaṃ labhate paurvadehikam
yatate ca tato bhūyaḥ saṃsiddhau kurunandana
en: Having obtained such a birth, the yogi regains naturally the same standard of spiritual vision he had acquired in his previous life, and in the light of that continues his practice with renewed zeal to perfect his Realization of God in this lifetime.

sa:
. पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः ।
जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते ॥
tl:
. pūrvābhyāsena tenaiva hriyate
hyavaśo’pi saḥ jijñāsurapi yogasya śabdabrahmātivartate
en: Those who take birth in an aware and wealthy family are certain to feel drawn towards the path of God Realization simply by the force of the habits acquired in their previous life. Thus, they continue their practice. Those who had become aware of the state of God Realization late in their last life also seek enlightenment in this life, and, practising, they too transcend their present level of consciousness.

sa:
. प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः ।
अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम् ॥
tl: . prayatnādyatamānastu yogī saṃśuddhakilbiṣaḥ anekajanmasaṃsiddhastato yāti parāṃ gatim
en: The yogi who becomes firmly aware of the state of unity with God diligently takes up the practice of Yog without interruption and, helped by the habits of his previous births, definitely attains perfection in this very life and enjoys Supreme Bliss.

sa:
. तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः ।
कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन ॥
tl:
. tapasvibhyo’dhiko yogī jñānibhyo’pi
mato’dhikaḥ karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna
en: The yogi who attempts to attain unity with God through meditation and the performance of good deeds is certain to attain Supreme Consciousness. He becomes totally one with Me. Therefore, Arjun, practise Oneness with Me.

sa:
. योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना ।
श्रद्धावान्भजते यो मां स मे युक्ततमो मतः ॥
tl:
. yogināmapi sarveṣāṃ madgatenāntarātmanā śraddhāvānbhajate
yo māṃ sa me yuktatamo mataḥ
en:
Among all the yogis desirous of attaining the perfect state of God Realization, I consider him to be the best who daily meditates on Me, worships Me, and holds always in his awareness that I alone am everywhere.
The chapter known as
DHYAAN YOG
ends.

sa:
श्रीभगवानुवाच मय्यासक्तमनाः पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रयः ।
असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु ॥
tl:
śrībhagavānuvāca mayyāsaktamanāḥ pārtha yogaṃ yuñjanmadāśrayaḥ
asaṃśayaṃ samagraṃ māṃ yathā jñāsyasi tacchṛṇu
en:
Shri Krishn said:
Arjun, having developed love for Me exclusively and being aware of your unity with Me, you will come to know Me as the Supreme Being. This Knowledge will make you free from all kinds of doubts.

sa:
. ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः ।
यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते ॥
tl: . jñānaṃ te’haṃ savijñānamidaṃ vakṣyāmyaśeṣataḥ yajjñātvā neha bhūyo’nyajjñātavyamavaśiṣyate
en: I shall speak to you of this Wisdom in its entirety. It will reveal the true nature of both the absolute formless aspect of God and the aspect of God with form. Having grasped this Knowledge, there will be nothing else in this world for you to know.

sa:
. मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये ।
यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्चिन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वतः ॥
tl:
. manuṣyāṇāṃ sahasreṣu kaścidyatati siddhaye
yatatāmapi siddhānāṃ kaścinmāṃ vetti tattvataḥ
en: This Knowledge of My true nature is so rare that only one among thousands of men strives to realize it; and, of those striving yogis, hardly one attains it.

sa:
. भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च ।
अहंकार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा ॥
tl:
. bhūmirāpo’nalo vāyuḥ khaṃ mano buddhireva
ca ahaṃkāra itīyaṃ me bhinnā prakṛtiraṣṭadhā
en: My obvious nature is divided eightfold into earth, water, fire, air, space, mind, intellect, and ego. These obvious factors constitute that division of Me called material nature.

sa:
. अपरेयमितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम् ।
जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत् ॥
tl:
. apareyamitastvanyāṃ prakṛtiṃ viddhi me
parām jīvabhūtāṃ mahābāho yayedaṃ dhāryate jagat
en: In addition to this division is My most refined nature, which is that form of Consciousness by which the universe is created and sustained. It is known as the “I”-consciousness in all beings, sentient and insentient, and it gives them life and the knowledge of their being and existence. It is also called jeev, or soul.

sa:
. एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणीत्युपधारय ।
अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगतः प्रभवः प्रलयस्तथा ॥
tl:
. etadyonīni bhūtāni sarvāṇītyupadhāraya
ahaṃ kṛtsnasya jagataḥ prabhavaḥ pralayastathā
en: These are the two aspects of My one nature. Prakriti and all beings have manifested from these aspects while I remain at the back of the entire creation as its source. I am the very Self from which all appear and into which all disappear.

sa:
. मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किंचिदस्ति धनंजय ।
मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव ॥
tl:
. mattaḥ parataraṃ nānyatkiṃcidasti dhanaṃjaya
mayi sarvamidaṃ protaṃ sūtre maṇigaṇā iva
en: Whether manifest or unmanifest, all is Me, Arjun. All the forms of the world are My manifest forms, threaded out of Me just as a string of beads may be formed by repeatedly knotting a single, continuous thread.

sa:
. रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययोः ।
प्रणवः सर्ववेदेषु शब्दः खे पौरुषं नृषु ॥
tl:
. raso’hamapsu kaunteya prabhāsmi śaśisūryayoḥ
praṇavaḥ sarvavedeṣu śabdaḥ khe pauruṣaṃ nṛṣu
en: Arjun, I am the essence of water and the light of the sun and moon. I am Pranav, the sacred syllable Om found in all the Vedas. I am sound in the aakaash, or space.

sa:
. पुण्योगन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ ।
जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु ॥
tl:
. puṇyogandhaḥ pṛthivyāṃ ca tejaścāsmi
vibhāvasau jīvanaṃ sarvabhūteṣu tapaścāsmi tapasviṣu
en: I am gandh, the inner existence of earth, and I am the pure brilliance of fire. I am the life in all beings. I am austerity in tapaswees, those who perform austerities.

sa:
. बीजं मां सर्वभूतानां विद्धि पार्थ सनातनम् ।
बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् ॥
tl:
. bījaṃ māṃ sarvabhūtānāṃ
viddhi pārtha sanātanam buddhirbuddhimatāmasmi tejastejasvināmaham
en: Arjun, know that I am the eternal seed existence of all existent beings. I am the intelligence of the intelligent. I am the glory of the glorious.

sa:
. बलं बलवतां चाहं कामरागविवर्जितम् ।
धर्माविरुद्धो भूतेषु कामोऽस्मि भरतर्षभ ॥
tl:
. balaṃ balavatāṃ cāhaṃ
kāmarāgavivarjitam dharmāviruddho bhūteṣu kāmo’smi bharatarṣabha
en: I am the might of mighty beings. I am free from passion and desire, yet, out of My freedom I emanate as the form of man’s desire for procreation.

sa:
. ये चैव सात्त्विका भावा राजसास्तामसाश्च ये ।
मत्त एवेति तान्विद्धि न त्वहं तेषु ते मयि ॥
tl:
. ye caiva sāttvikā bhāvā rājasāstāmasāśca ye
matta eveti tānviddhi na tvahaṃ teṣu te mayi
en: Whatever entities there are, whether born of sattwa, the quality of knowledge which makes one aware of Me, or of rajas, the quality of knowledge by which action is continued, or of tamas, the power by which activity ceases to be, all are evolved from Me and Me alone. It is said that I exist in them or they exist in Me, but one will be mistaken if he understands this in the same way that he understands a man to exist in a house or food to exist in the stomach. In reality, I am the Whole and the Whole is Me, as water is ice and ice is water.

sa:
. त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत् ।
मोहितं नाभिजानाति मामेभ्यः परमव्ययम् ॥
tl: . tribhirguṇamayairbhāvairebhiḥ sarvamidaṃ jagat mohitaṃ nābhijānāti māmebhyaḥ paramavyayam
en: Due to the functioning of My Prakriti, which uses its three states of consciousness, sattwa, rajas, and tamas, to evolve objects, man in general has forgotten that I am the sole Reality of the world. Worldly minds fail to realize Me as the single Reality, which never increases, never decreases.

sa:
. दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया ।
मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते ॥
tl:
. daivī hyeṣā guṇamayī mama māyā
duratyayā māmeva ye prapadyante māyāmetāṃ taranti te
en: My most miraculous force of Maayaa, consisting of the three gunas－sattwa, rajas, and tamas－is extremely difficult to understand for those who have not become one with My Consciousness. They stay bound by their own ignorance. But those who constantly worship Me are freed and come to know the reality of Maayaa.

sa:
. न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः ।
माययापहृतज्ञाना आसुरं भावमाश्रिताः ॥
tl:
. na māṃ duṣkṛtino mūḍhāḥ
prapadyante narādhamāḥ māyayāpahṛtajñānā āsuraṃ bhāvamāśritāḥ
en: Those whose minds have been carried away by the force of ignorance and have embraced the demonic remain busy with their evil deeds. Such foolish men never adore Me.

sa:
. चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन ।
आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानी च भरतर्षभ ॥
tl:
. caturvidhā bhajante māṃ janāḥ
sukṛtino’rjuna ārto jijñāsurarthārthī jñānī ca bharatarṣabha
en: Arjun, four types of devotees, all of whom are good, worship Me: those who seek worldly prosperity, those who want to rid themselves of pain and affliction, those who want to understand why they are here on earth and what will happen to them after they die, and those who want to attain the Knowledge of their true nature.

sa:
. तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते ।
प्रियो हि ज्ञानिनोऽत्यर्थमहं स च मम प्रियः ॥
tl:
. teṣāṃ jñānī nityayukta ekabhaktirviśiṣyate priyo
hi jñānino’tyarthamahaṃ sa ca mama priyaḥ
en: Arjun, of these four categories of men, the man of Wisdom reaches Me the soonest. He is established in identity with Me and is possessed of perfect devotion. To such a person I am extremely dear, and that wise one is extremely dear to Me.

sa:
. उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम् ।
आस्थितः स हि युक्तात्मा मामेवानुत्तमां गतिम् ॥
tl:
. udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me
matam āsthitaḥ sa hi yuktātmā māmevānuttamāṃ gatim
en: I have described the nobility of all these men to you, but the man of Wisdom knows that he is not at all separate from Me. This devoted one, who has transcended his sense of duality, has become firmly established in that Consciousness which is one with Me. This is man’s highest goal.

sa:
. बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते ।
वासुदेवः सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभः ॥
tl:
. bahūnāṃ janmanāmante jñānavānmāṃ prapadyate
vāsudevaḥ sarvamiti sa mahātmā sudurlabhaḥ
en: Arjun, such a noble soul is very rare who realizes in this lifetime that all is God.

sa:
. कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः ।
तं तं नियममास्थाय प्रकृत्या नियताः स्वया ॥
tl:
. kāmaistaistairhṛtajñānāḥ prapadyante’nyadevatāḥ taṃ
taṃ niyamamāsthāya prakṛtyā niyatāḥ svayā
en: He whose intellect has been carried away by the various desires for the enjoyment of sense objects is under the sway of his own karm, or habit patterns. Thus, he worships not Me but the deities, or powers, following the rituals pertaining to each.

sa:
. यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति ।
तस्य तस्याचलां श्रद्धां तामेव विदधाम्यहम् ॥
tl:
. yo yo yāṃ yāṃ tanuṃ
bhaktaḥ śraddhayārcitumicchati tasya tasyācalāṃ śraddhāṃ tāmeva vidadhāmyaham
en: Since I am at the back of every man’s thought, I make stable the faith of any devotee who chooses to worship with reverence one of the various principals of My power.

sa:
. स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते ।
लभते च ततः कामान् मयैव विहितान्हि तान् ॥
tl:
. sa tayā śraddhayā yuktastasyārādhanamīhate labhate
ca tataḥ kāmān mayaiva vihitānhi tān
en: Without fail, he obtains his desired enjoyment through the worship of that particular power because it is Me who has ordained My powers to the heads of the various departments of manifestation, such as fire, air, or water.

sa:
. अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम् ।
देवान्देवयजो यान्ति मद्भक्ता यान्ति मामपि ॥
tl:
. antavattu phalaṃ teṣāṃ tadbhavatyalpamedhasām
devāndevayajo yānti madbhaktā yānti māmapi
en: But Arjun, the happiness gained by these people of small understanding is perishable. The worshippers of gods attain the results of their worship only to the extent that such gods can offer; whereas, the devotees who worship Me ultimately attain My Consciousness and are established in Me alone.

sa:
. अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः ।
परं भावमजानन्तो ममाव्ययमनुत्तमम् ॥
tl: . avyaktaṃ vyaktimāpannaṃ manyante māmabuddhayaḥ paraṃ bhāvamajānanto mamāvyayamanuttamam
en: Ignorant believers know Me as something beyond the reach of their minds and senses. If at all they try to understand Me, the embodiment of Pure Consciousness, Existence, and Bliss, they conclude that I have become a finite form by taking birth as an ordinary human being.

sa:
. नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः ।
मूढोऽयं नाभिजानाति लोको मामजमव्ययम् ॥
tl:
. nāhaṃ prakāśaḥ sarvasya
yogamāyāsamāvṛtaḥ mūḍho’yaṃ nābhijānāti loko māmajamavyayam
en: The reason, Arjun, is that I am concealed by My own Yog Maayaa, the force of creation, and so am not manifest to all. Thus, many people, who appear to be ignorant, cannot recognize Me as the Supreme Being unless they are informed of the fact that I am never subject to birth and death.

sa:
. वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन ।
भविष्याणि च भूतानि मां तु वेद न कश्चन ॥
tl:
. vedāhaṃ samatītāni vartamānāni cārjuna bhaviṣyāṇi
ca bhūtāni māṃ tu veda na kaścana
en: I am the One, Arjun, who is knowing all beings, in the past, in the present, and even in the future. This is because My true nature is the substance of Knowingness, of which all this manifestation appears. So, I am said to know the past, present, and future.

sa:
. इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत ।
सर्वभूतानि संमोहं सर्गे यान्ति परंतप ॥
tl:
. icchādveṣasamutthena dvandvamohena bhārata
sarvabhūtāni saṃmohaṃ sarge yānti paraṃtapa
en: Arjun, they who through My power of division perceive objects separate from Me remain bound in the struggle born of desire and hatred and keep falling prey to the sense of duality.

sa:
. येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम् ।
ते द्वन्द्वमोहनिर्मुक्ता भजन्ते मां दृढव्रताः ॥
tl:
. yeṣāṃ tvantagataṃ pāpaṃ janānāṃ
puṇyakarmaṇām te dvandvamohanirmuktā bhajante māṃ dṛḍhavratāḥ
en: But they who have performed virtuous deeds, who have become free from delusion and, thus, free from struggle in the field of the pairs of opposites, they devote their minds to Me with firm conviction and worship Me in every way.

sa:
. जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये ।
ते ब्रह्म तद्विदुः कृत्स्नमध्यात्मं कर्म चाखिलम् ॥
tl:
. jarāmaraṇamokṣāya māmāśritya yatanti ye
te brahma tadviduḥ kṛtsnamadhyātmaṃ karma cākhilam
en:
They who take refuge in Me for deliverance from old age and death practise My teachings with steadfastness. They come to realize the nature of Brahm and the nature of adhyaatm, the embodied soul. They also become aware of the entire field of action and of My total Being comprising adhibhoot, the field of matter, and Brahmaa, the Creator. They grasp the reality of My nature by which I dwell in the hearts of all beings in the form of awareness. Since their consciousness becomes transformed into the Vision of Oneness, they know Me even at the hour of death.
The chapter known as Gyaan Vigyaan Yog ends.

sa:
साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः ।
प्रयाणकालेऽपि च मां ते विदुर्युक्तचेतसः ॥
tl:
sādhibhūtādhidaivaṃ māṃ sādhiyajñaṃ ca ye
viduḥ prayāṇakāle’pi ca māṃ te viduryuktacetasaḥ
en:
They who take refuge in Me for deliverance from old age and death practise My teachings with steadfastness. They come to realize the nature of Brahm and the nature of adhyaatm, the embodied soul. They also become aware of the entire field of action and of My total Being comprising adhibhoot, the field of matter, and Brahmaa, the Creator. They grasp the reality of My nature by which I dwell in the hearts of all beings in the form of awareness. Since their consciousness becomes transformed into the Vision of Oneness, they know Me even at the hour of death.
The chapter known as Gyaan Vigyaan Yog ends.

sa:
अर्जुन उवाच किं तत् ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम ।
अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते ॥
tl:
arjuna uvāca kiṃ tat brahma kimadhyātmaṃ kiṃ
karma puruṣottama adhibhūtaṃ ca kiṃ proktamadhidaivaṃ kimucyate
en:
Arjun asked:
Krishn, tell me about Brahm, the Absolute; adhyaatm, the spirit; karm, action; and also about adhibhoot, matter. And let me know, what is Adhidaiv, the Divine Intelligence?

sa:
अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन ।
प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः ॥
tl:
adhiyajñaḥ kathaṃ ko’tra dehe’sminmadhusūdana
prayāṇakāle ca kathaṃ jñeyo’si niyatātmabhiḥ
en: Also, Krishn, let me know, who is Adhiyagya, the Witness Self? How does he dwell in the body, and how are You, the very Self of all, to be realized at the time of death by those who are devoted to You?

sa:
श्रीभगवानुवाच अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते ।
भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः ॥
tl: śrībhagavānuvāca akṣaraṃ brahma paramaṃ svabhāvo’dhyātmamucyate bhūtabhāvodbhavakaro visargaḥ karmasaṃjñitaḥ
en:
Shri Krishn replied:
Supreme, indestructible Existence is known by the word Brahm; one’s own Self as the individual soul is called adhyaatm; and the forces which bring forth the existence of the Pure Being are called action, or karm. Thus, all beings in material existence have spirit and action as their form.

sa:
. अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम् ।
अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर ॥
tl:
. adhibhūtaṃ kṣaro bhāvaḥ
puruṣaścādhidaivatam adhiyajño’hamevātra dehe dehabhṛtāṃ vara
en: Perishable objects are called adhibhoot; the shining Consciousness is called Adhidaiv; and I am the One who, dwelling as the inner witness in every body, is called Adhiyagya, the Knower, the basis of the idea “I am” in all beings.

sa:
. अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम् ।
यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः ॥
tl:
. antakāle ca māmeva smaranmuktvā kalevaram
yaḥ prayāti sa madbhāvaṃ yāti nāstyatra saṃśayaḥ
